Let‚Äôs be fair, there is no medium where the majority of works aren‚Äôt iterations on elements from other works. Even Dark Souls pieces together clear inspirations from games that came before it (King‚Äôs Field, Ocarina of Time, Castlevania, the entire roguelike genre). Critics and producers use comparisons to well-known works to describe something to people who haven‚Äôt seen/played it before all the time. The question isn‚Äôt whether the individual components of a piece of art are all ‚Äúoriginal‚Äù (whatever that means - just about everything‚Äôs been done by someone at some point) but whether they‚Äôre used in an inspired way.

OK I'm confused. What's this video trying to say? STealing ideas is bad? Games need more originality? Commentators please stop comparing games with similar mechanics to each other?  Really don't understand the meta on this one. Games are just like any other art form. The more contributions made to the art form, the more rare true originality is going to become. Like when have you ever heard a band that wasn't influenced by other bands? How are you supposed to describe a band to someone else without discussing the bands that influenced them?
Brilliant point by Dunkey. When we talk about games by just comparing them to other games, we discourage originality and reinforce the notion that there are only a few ways of making a video game by making original concepts (or the borrowing of good ones/inevitable ones) out as a direct ripoff of something else. We should start appreciating quality games for what they are, not what we ascribe them to be trying to imitate, regardless of if they are or not.
Can you imagine journalism like this back in the 90s. "It's mario but your a monkey." It's like zelda but in space. This game take elements from mario and zelda.

I get the joke but like‚Ä¶ there is no game possible that couldn‚Äôt be compared to a popular game or two. It‚Äôs extremely useful shorthand to convey the general concept of the game by using other known games as reference points. Why waste time explaining every game‚Äôs mechanics from scratch when you can get a rough idea of the basis of the game in a single sentence? I‚Äôd bet a lot of the games they are comparing to popular games aren‚Äôt even *that* unoriginal. It‚Äôs faster to say ‚Äúit‚Äôs kinda like dark souls‚Äù than ‚Äúit‚Äôs a third person fantasy adventure game featuring slow, meticulous combat with focus on strict timing and stamina management, where the consequences of failure are great.‚Äù And that wouldn‚Äôt even get into things such as type of story / lore, if you wanted to explain how hand holdy it is or how much of the lore is hidden or open to interpretation, etc etc. that would take ages and be hella boring

So utterly sick of people acting like BotW invented the stamina-based climbing and roaming vast, breathtaking landscapes.  You know what game did stamina-based climbing leagues better 12 years earlier? Shadow of the Colossus.  You know what game did vast, breathtaking landscapes leagues better 15 years earlier? The Elder Scrolls III: Morrowind.  You know what game did hang-gliding leagues better 17 years earlier? Banjo-Tooie.  I didn't even like BotW, but I'd give it all the credit in the world if people would just stop propping it up like it actually did anything truly innovative. And no, weapons breaking after 11 hits does not count.  Also Demon's Souls did stamina management and weapon durability better.

the system you use to describe or represent what you know, can't exceed the maximum combination of it's elements (even if that combination is infinite, for example like the combinations of numbers , you can't use them to create something new, because 'new' will mean elements not present  or created  with that system)

A game so good that if it's an rpg or has in-depth mechanics and is somewhat hard, then it's Dark Souls clone in the form of a soulslike.   Imagine making a few games like that and they all have to use the interconnected world and rely on some form of dodge and when it's not slow, or way too fast, or doesn't rely on using a dodge roll, or is so much longer, and has an open world, it sucks and the "series isn't what it was supposed to be." Nintendo could do with some originality, actually. Their huge success in the 1990s was partially owed to the amount of care they put into dozens of original franchises which people still adore to this day. Alas, Nintendo knows this, so they continue to milk their biggest cash cows because people will buy them regardless of innovation and Nintendo therefore doesn't need to take the risks that come with originality.  Their only significant recent(ish) original franchise is Splatoon, a multiplayer title that came about out of necessity. Nintendo was lacking market dominance in online multiplayer and Splatoon was simply their answer to that problem.  Maybe if Nintendo stopped producing rehashes and instead worked on new franchises, other developers would stop trying to imitate them... a result of the Nintendo games still being popular. (Obviously wishful thinking, but y'know, would be nice.)

When marketing a game developers are taught pretty heavily that users lack the ability to perceive anything that doesn‚Äôt already exist. Which basically requires you to describe your game as being a composite of other games.  Ironically this is especially true if your game actually ISN‚ÄôT like any other game out there. When that‚Äôs the case it‚Äôs twice as important you can describe it to the user in terms of other games. Honestly idk if this is true and users really can‚Äôt grasp new game ideas, it seems like we‚Äôre not giving them enough credit. But us devs are taught this is a major crux of marketing your game, and the data unfortunately reflects in favor of this tactic.

Every form of media -- books, tv shows, movies, and of course games -- are inspired by and borrow elements from their contemporaries. It's natural and can help lead to evolution. The real problem is when these newer games are just derivative. That being said, game reviews have this special problem where they reeeeeaally like saying "game x is like game y", which can sometimes downplay the original concepts they do bring to the table.

This happens a lot with critics and is often, in my opinion, the sign of a lazy critic. For example in music I'll see a lot of people just refer to the influences an artist has drawn on rather than looking at the actual merits of the work. E.g. when the new Black Country, New Road album came out so many people would say they loved (and some hated) the Arcade Fire influence in it. This is a valid reason to like a project for most people, but when you're a professional art critic, there should be an expectation to look a bit deeper than surface level observations of a project's influences that most people could make.

People think Dunkey is making some statement about videogame journalism and not lack of originality in videogames smh. The industry is infected with sameness because the aim of a AAA videogame is, first and foremost, to sell a lot of copies. This is because the creative vision of the creators (if one assumes there was one before it was mutilated into tried and tested videogame formulas) often has to be sacrificed in order to appeal to investors, which secures the continued survival of the company. Every game shown in this video is a recreation of something tried and tested, which becomes endlessly reproduced because the consumer time and again shows a willingness to buy the tried and tested formula (with minor variations such as *replace assassin with samurai*, *move 3d perspective to 2d*, etc. etc.) Dark Souls is worthy of comparison because it took actual creative risks. Risks in storytelling, difficulty and gameplay elements which made the game itself inaccesible to the mainstream, and thereby detaches it from the industry standard and transforms it into something more than mere commodity. Furthermore, the risk it took actually paid off! This is such an excellent achievement.  Games *such as* Dark Souls come around once in a while, everything in between those are just industry filler looking for a handout from the people who are either unable to look past the sameness in the industry or willing to accept it.
I‚Äôve learned that comparisons are only references in video game reviews. A good focal point to which you can compare something to.

‚Ä¶yes, people like to use comparisons to familiar things in order to describe similar, novel things. Does Dunk think he‚Äôs making some grand revelation with this video? As someone who's been gaming for over 30 years, I do feel a resonance with this. It seems similar to the way pop and rock music became a phenomenon in the mid 20th century, but now musicians rely on a syncretism of different styles to create something new. I find that whenever I see a game review, I tend to just think in the same terms of the reviewers, "So it's Dark Souls with JRPG elements" or "It's like Civ but with fantasy elements." For the last ten years or so, I've found nothing wrong with this, as it's sometimes those mix-ups that produce a very enjoyable product. However, as someone who largely feels done with gaming and plays very rarely now, I do struggle to find the sense of awe and wonder that I used to in years passed. Currently playing Elden Ring, and the creativity and artistry is truly fantastic. That alone can be reason sufficient to continue. At the half way mark now, though, I can feel my desire to continue waning, for no other reason than "I feel I've seen this all before". I don't think this is the game's fault either, and for those who have not experienced as many iterations of the formula, (or simply not been playing 3D action RPGs since Ocarina of Time was first released), it will most likely be an intensely enjoyable experience. As for those who feel jaded with gaming however, I think it will take a quantum shift in game technology to inspire the aforementioned sense of awe and wonder once again. Perhaps when AI has reached such a level that I could have a conversation with NPCs in plain English and have them respond realistically, or a physics engine that represented true to life responses given any theoretical action I took in the game.

Taking inspiration and even flat out copying GOOD mechanics from other games isn't inherently bad. It's if those mechanics fit the game and what else new/unique stuff the game has to offer to justify its existence.
‚ÄúNothing is original. Steal from anywhere that resonates with inspiration or fuels your imagination. Devour old films, new films, music, books, paintings, photographs, poems, dreams, random conversations, architecture, bridges, street signs, trees, clouds, bodies of water, light and shadows. Select only things to steal from that speak directly to your soul. If you do this, your work (and theft) will be authentic. Authenticity is invaluable; originality is non-existent. And don‚Äôt bother concealing your thievery - celebrate it if you feel like it. In any case, always remember what Jean-Luc Godard said: ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not where you take things from - it‚Äôs where you take them to."   - Don Cheadle

Finally someone brings up this issue with gaming journalists
I can't blame them too much, it's the easiest way to describe and pitch a videogame.  To be honest, every game is inspired by another game's idea.  BOTW's got HEAVY similarities to Shadow of the Colossus.  What makes a game original to me, is taking multiple (not just one) idea fun elements to games and combining the fun elements one likes, leaving one's own personality in their creation and making something new out of multiple, borrowed elements.  This goes with story, music, painting/drawings, character designs, all of it.  Even Mario's platforming was just an expanded idea of Donkey Kong, with the discovery of side-scrolling.  Then all other games like Metal Slug, Sonic, Megaman, and others took to make their own flavor of that formula.  This criticism just doesn't seem warranted.  I mean "Dreams" was an original idea for a console game, and it kinda sucked!

I get the criticism and that all the comparing that goes on can sometimes be a bit ridiculous, like when people feel the need to mention that something is a bit like Dark Souls just because it has difficult combat or some such contrived loose similarity. That being said, I often find comparison to be one of the most efficient ways to describe a game when used appropriately.  For example, "Dying Light is Dead Island meets Mirror's Edge". That's very accurate and succinct. That's not all it is, but it's a very good starting point for a longer explanation, or about as good as it gets for a quick answer said in passing you might give a friend who asks what Dying Light is like.

I never understood why a lot of devs hate on media outlets title dropping when describing their games. But now I do.
We're at the point in the gaming industry where its impossible to create a new game without it being immediately compared to something else, because almost everything you can think of is going to be similar to another game. Its not really a bad thing, its not even a case of oversaturation, it was just inevitable we'd get to the point where so many things can be similar to one another.  The Music Industry is kind of like this too, in that in each Genre you will find songs similar to each other fairly often, though atleast in the case of Video Games its easier to distinguish yourself despite the similarities to other games.

pain
While you mock the reviewers for comparing games to other games so much, you forget the fact that most people really like for games to be compared to other games they enjoy - because, we, as humans, really like being able to relate things to other things - it makes intuitive sense, and we are much more able to understand the deviations and novelties when we have set a base.   If I tell you "hollow knight is a mix of dark souls and metroidvania", you instantly get a clear picture of what the basics of the game are. At this point, it is much easier to understand new things added on top of it, like, "there is a bigger focus on boss fights, with tight, precise movements, while having an extremely well crafted environment and level design that allows players to quickly understand any new ability they find, while never locking them away/making them feel lost, leading to hollow knight being amongst the best of both genre on these points alone"  Without the comparison, you'd have to explain a lot more, delve a lot deeper without much value added to the discussion. This is why we label things into genres, be it for movies, music, ect.  Originality itself, isn't purely 100% out of nowhere. every "new" thing is a derivative of an older thing, that expanded upon a basis in ways unforeseen. You can compare mario to early arcade platformers, you can compare video games to choose your own adventure books/toys (which nintendo did a lot with the nes), you can compare the invention of fire with lightning strikes leading to forest fires, but on a much more focused and smaller scale.  Criticizing reviewers over making basic comparisons between video games before delving into the differences and how the developers innovate is just, in my opinion, stupid  On the other hand, critics who make comparisons and *only* comparisons without never actually explaining the differences or how they even apply ie "this really is the dark souls of puzzle games", these are perfectly valid. But the examples you gave seem more than genuine, hence why I kind of dislike how you presented it.

On another note, this is how sales works in all creative industries. In fact I wouldnt be surprised if reviewers and vloggers were required by supervisors to compare the game to other games. The reason ‚Äúelevator pitches‚Äù tend to reference already established products is because marketing begins at the very beginning of the creative process. The way the game will be marketed to audiences that like similar games actually affects the way the game is developed. Producers and executives want a new product to feel familiar but have a slight edge over another one. It‚Äôs the same problem in the movie industry and the music industry as well, and the reason why changes to what is mainstream happen so slowly.   On the other hand when a product/game/artist breaks a convention successfully, The rest of the industry will Quickly copy and paste the innovation, even if it feels forced. Ie the breath of the wild stamina bar.
Wow no dunkey til 3:20. Really interesting how Dunkey is letting the game culture clown itself

And to be real, originality wasn't ever that big of a deal of video games. Look at Mario. The amount of 2D platformer copycats that flooded the market after Mario came out set a precedent that has never been exceeded. And that was back with video games were still on their infancy. Alternative title: "Originality in Video Game Journalism"
To be fair, the Dark Souls as a game at its release was heavily criticized by the PC community, especially in the cRPG scene. To use a Gamepay instead of a Mouse & Keyboard was frowned upon (and still might be in some circles). There was a present stigma against it because it didn't really follow the cRPG dogmatic, but in its purest form the Dark Souls was a modern game with a spin on the concept that exists solely on the older classic game mechanics and severe punishments. To the typical modern casual gamer that lives off Shenmue's QTA barrage in "games" like Assassin's Creed, Dark Souls indeed was a hard pill to swallow. Some newer generations had a chance to experience a fraction of the punishing aspects of the older NES/SNES/GENS golden era without actually playing them. In reality, the popularity of Dark Souls is well deserved because it paved the road towards what games should/can be about, rather than lootbox simulators that delve on the concept of gambling. In time, the gaming community recognized these attributes which led towards Dark Souls' massive recognition to the point of having a somewhat "mini" genre of "Souls-like" games, akin to "Diablo clones".  Dark Souls felt like a game from the era of 1999. and for what it's worth it is amazing to see that even a highly stigmatized game from Japan can redefine and show what the gaming community wants. Unfortunately, various indie and other types of developers believe that the game should be a copy/paste in terms of the mechanics and/or difficulty, in some cases even increasing it. But without really delivering a believable and well made story, atmosphere, setting and so forth. This in turn creates a negative effect because the scene gets oversaturated, so you end up disliking the "Souls-like" games because they're not really Dark Souls. You get bored of the concept, which is only natural.  Dark Souls was a tiny bit of innovative force in an already oversaturated market a decade ago. It gave a much needed foundation to build upon, and I'd say that gaming did change somewhat for the better ever since. Especially in the Indie scene.

Originality has never been our specialty as humans. Even if something is totally original we try to make connections to what we are familiar with. A lot of psychology professors will tell you originality doesn't exist. Just slight variations of the familiar. Seriously test it yourself. Come up with a game idea or mechanics without any inspiration from another game. You'll just end up with a combination of things from games you love.

A game or movie does really well and next thing you know everything is trying to get that same magic and success for their product. It even happens in music. I don't think it's inherently cynical either, I mean that's how we get innovations, someone has to be inspired by something and say "I think I could do that but better". Best case scenario we get innovators, worst case scenario we get cheap knock offs but the latter is usually detected in society and that tends to take care of itself. I mean nothing is black and white but that's my general perception of the situation. Games are getting stale though, I've been saying that for years. It feels like the golden age is over so to speak. I mean if your point is to criticize IGN's reduction of video games to the things that inspired/influenced them then I totally agree. If you mean to say that games are unoriginal then I must disagree. Of course, in recent years a lot of franchises played it safe, but as with movies, inspiration and influence is unavoidable and still leads to really cool and fresh stuff (like star wars when the first one came out). We have been recycling stories and tropes since the ancient greek era.
Nintendo released Breath of the Wild and every studio making an open world game was like "I want that"
I honestly feel like it's video game review channels and journalists that need to have some reporting too. Just because you see the same mechanic of one game inside another, doesn't automatically make it like that game. Say I make a cowboy-esque game set in the future that features a slow time feature while in combat. You may say that's a rdr copy in a huge way. But you fail to recognize that being able to shoot faster than a bullet or faster than the other guy has been a heavy trope of the wild-west media genre. And that cowboys and outlaws and almost movie-like shootouts are cool as hell and not just a copy of rdr. Say the lassos in this game like electricity ropes cause you need to be able to stun a robot who otherwise will have the strength to break free of a typical lasso. Or now you can use your horse for cover while riding by hanging on to the side of its body cause it's not even real, it's a robot one. But you can use a real horse because it doesn't have a chance of "malfunctioning" when an EMP grenade is used, the food and care required for isn't as expensive as constantly repairing and fueling a robot one. And you have to think about the gear/horse you take with you to certain areas/targets because robots and humans offer different challenges. Not to question your own character. If you're a robot, you can have parts built into you but it might irritate/overwork your robot body depending on if you use too many at once, use a weapon that requires cool downs, etc. . However if you're a human, you can throw as many utilities and weapons as your two arms allow you without becoming over fatigued, you just can't pull them out as fast maybe or you can't store as many weapons on your person. That's ANOTHER THING, the whole getting weapons and equipment from your horse. That may be seen as another attempt at copying Red Dead but where the hell else will you keep your weapons? In your ass like most other rockstar games?   What I'm getting at here is that just because a few elements are drawn form one game to another, that doesn't make the second game a copy or something that heavily draws from the first game. They're just elements that make sense to put into a game, like a stamina bar for climbing and sprinting. Or rolling to get away from an enemy that requires great skill and persistence to beat.  Not saying that blatant copying doesn't happen, cause it definitely does, just not on the scale that many believe IMO
I dont see any problems with these reviews personally...if a game is similar/takes clear inspirations from another game, its the  reviewers duty to  report on it. When a music journalist is reviewing a music piece they always lay out the similarities or inspirations that they took from another artist. I dont see this as lazy writing really. I do not understand this video. Of course games are similar to one another, just like everything in every category. If I wanted to describe Daft Punk, I could explicitly describe all of their technology and techniques, or I could say that it‚Äôs a 2000s techno band that has its roots in stuff like Kraftwerk. Does that make it derivative? No, of course not. Are there a lot of other bands that are based on Kraftwerk? Absolutely. Does that make Daft Punk similar to DEVO, another band that‚Äôs similar to Kraftwerk? Of course not - they sound completely different. I am surprised to see a talented reviewer such as Dunkey misunderstand this.

I think this suffers from a crippling lack of being able to describe the game itself... so reviewers have to allude to other games to make the connection to their viewers. While this isn't inherently wrong, the over reliance is clearly showcased in the above video. If too many people reference the same games for seemingly anything with a playable space larger than a 5 x 5 apartment, or reference the same game for anything relating to i-frames, the problem becomes incredibly apparent.  It's like the meme where Destiny was called something alone the lines of: Star Duty Call of Battlefield: Remastered Limited Edition. Just a mix of the most buzz wordy titles to describe anything.  tbh, the viewers of the review should be determining what the game relates to other games. The game reviewers (while they can do that) should first describe the game itself and its mechanics thoroughly before CONCLUDING that said game being reviewed is like other games (that they've hopefully reviewed / played as well).

I feel like a lot of those games aren't anything like dark souls, but a lot of the commentators know that if they say that, then people would think its challenging. The point of the video still stands. I don't mind people taking inspiration from different games myself, since there tends to be a progression that sometimes pushes the type of game further when they add aspects that were good about a previous game and build on it, but it would be nice to see more new ideas on the market.   It's hard to think out o0f the box some times to make things completely new where it can't be compared to other games, especially since its so hard to break the trends of games now a days. This isn't revolutionary, but one thing I would love to see in games now a days, is the use of modular systems, where you could create your own custom gear, abilities and spells through a modular system. It's been tried a few times, and every time it has been extremely fun in the games that they were implemented.  The magica series did this very well where the spell that you cast are combinations of elements that you put together when casting the spell, making it feel as if you are actually casting a spell. Ars magica mod for mincraft did even better where you could expend resources to create your own entirely custom spell pages that have what feels like infinite possibility for creativity. Playing that mod made you actually feel like you are a mage discovering entirely new magic in your tower. It would be wonderful to see those sort of implementations in many genres across the board. I would especially like to see it in top down rpgs, mmos, and hack and slashes.   The same goes for modular gear. Warframe attempted it, and had some success with it by making weapons that you could combine four separate types of pieces to change the stats of the final weapon. The downside to that is for the most part it was just base stat adjustments instead of something that is more inspirational. Back to minecraft mods, there is a mod called tinkers construct that allows a lot of different weapon and tool bases that could be put together as differing materials, many of them giving a lot of interesting effects, upsides and downsides. They also had modifier slots that could add some very interesting and unique abilities on them. Things like that and possibly armor would be excellent for the previously mentioned game types.
And at the end of the day, every game is just a carbon copy of Knack and Knack 2

I don't think this video adds anything helpful to the conversation... There are definitely a lot of derivative games out there, but that's the case for every art medium. Music, movies, books, painting... They all have waves of someone doing something revolutionary, people taking inspiration from it (oftentimes too heavily), and the new idea getting played out. Meanwhile, someone else is already creating the next innovation.  This video seems to me to cherry-pick some of the most egregious game reviews and presents them as what all gaming journalism and boundary-pushing has boiled down to. But it's not that bad. While there is definitely a lot of derivative fad-chasing in games that means you can safely ignore a lot of samey titles, that's the case in every art form. It's a perfectly normal part of the evolution of pop culture. It doesn't mean we've reached a dead end.

I don't think this is necessarily a bad thing. To be clear, there are instances where a comparison isn't really warranted... or rather, just straight up doesn't work. But a lot of times, a game can genuinely be original, but pull elements from other games. And there are enough games out there that most games have some similarities to others. If it gives an accurate idea of the game, its not necessarily a bad thing.

This videos just proves why you should play games for story before gameplay
Of course game reviewers are going to compare one game to another, it helps people understand what they might be getting into before playing the game. If I asked someone what a new shooter is like and they say it's like CSGO, or R6 Siege, or Overwatch, or Apex Legends, or CoD, you instantly get some idea of what the gameplay might be like; much more so than saying "it's a team based shooter". Sharing some mechanics or flavour doesn't necessarily mean a game is a clone, or doesn't bring something new to the table.  If Dunkey's point here is that there are no new ideas in games because, hey look, all the reviewers compare new games to old games then it's a pretty bad take.  The question you should be asking here though is: are these games just taking inspiration, or are they leaning too heavily on popular mechanics and themes from other games?

On one hand, video games are getting kinda stale and uninspired. On the other, there are only so many ways to design a game before you refine your process to an inevitable point that you're basically just doing the same thing as everyone else in your genre. Same goes for other creative forms like movies and music. You think about how many EDM songs sound the same, or horror movies basically follow the same plot, just with different characters. I feel like its only natural that game studios would whittle away what doesn't work until they're basically mirrors of one another.

Sure games, particularly high budget have an 'Originality Issue', but these are all snippets from reviews. Reviewers are giving understandable elevator pitches to audiences who are curious if the game is to their taste. Comparisons are just the easiest way to do that. I have plenty of issues with games journalism and prefer deep analysis, but initial reviews that are tailored to general audiences with the attention span of roughly 5 minutes? Not a big deal.

This video seems like it‚Äôs in poor taste. Of course reviewers compare games to other games - it‚Äôs the most efficient way of letting players know what the game is like. Don‚Äôt like Dark Souls type combat? Then hearing a reviewer compare something‚Äôs combat to Dark Souls will probably save you from a purchase you end up disliking. People will often search for games similar to games they played and enjoyed, so hearing that one game is like another will probably help them out. Sure, if the reviewer exclusively used comparisons then it would be a poor review, but taking a few seconds to make comparisons is pretty apt I think.

Wittgenstein argued that things often don't have one single identifying aspect that uniquely identifies them, but instead have "family resemblances". A lot of overlapping similarities, by which they appear to sit in one family or more. Wittgenstein used games as his examples of things which can only be explained as a family resemblance. If you could find a way of defining what a game definitively is without using family resemblances, then you could disprove the greatest philosopher of the 20th century.
Nothing exists in a vacuum. Everything takes inspiration from everything else. And Dark Souls.

Journalists usually read from press kit given to them by the developers themselves. It's not necessarily lack of originality but rather them thinking that "player are more likely to pickup a game that seems similar to what they already know."  Whether this is true or not depends who you ask and how you look at the market.  Even when studying game design, we HAD to take inspiration from something. It could be from a real life experience/activity, but with the market being what it is, it's more likely that a game will be similar to another game.

Moral of the story: Devil May Cry was original
n64 games were pretty much entirely original because they were the first games to use the third dimension; oot is still the goat, imo, but that's for many reasons, including originality. Otherwise, every new game will always borrow from what's come before to a certain extent, that's just how any culture, video-game or other, works. I think originality comes, apart from introducing a new spatial dimension, from taking what's come before and mixing it together in such a way that produces something that hasn't been seen before: DS was so fresh because we'd never had a Zelda game that challenging or dark before--it's like they mixed Castlevania and Zelda together--; Metroid Prime was a metroidvania mixed with fps, never been done before. I think for something to be original, it has to mix to sources together, which mixture is entirely new; or else it needs to borrow from a variety of different sources, which have already been mixed before, but  use a fresh new ratio in balancing those influences which ratio is significantly different to any ratio used in that same mix before.

Art is never original to a default. It's most likely that you copy something or getispired by other Art and add something new to it. Nothing wrong with that.

It‚Äôs very hard to be completely original with games lately, but taking ideas in many other games and combining it with your own unique idea is a perfectly fine strategy. I think the reviewers know this, but their constant comparisons to other games and how they word it tend to give off a bad impression to the audience. It‚Äôs fine to say what something in a game reminds you of, but if you describe a game as just an amalgamation of a bunch of other games, then that takes away that game‚Äôs individuality. Dunkey‚Äôs probably aware of this, and other people have brought things like this up before, I don‚Äôt really know who my target audience is.

I can't tell if the video is meant to be commentary on gaming journalism, or the gaming industry.  If it's the former, it makes sense that quicker reviews would try to distill down what a game is about by relating it to other successful games in the genre. It's reasonable when there's meaningful overlap. You can say more with less, assuming your audience is familiar with those titles. Plus it gives a good foundation for what reviews are meant to be -- Should you play this game? Well, if you like X, Y, and Z games, maybe you should!  Can these shortcuts be used to create lazy, shallow reviews? Unfortunately, yep.  If it's the latter, everything that anything in these reviews is compared to was once compared to something else, which was compared to something else.  To say something is unoriginal just because you can point at pieces that resemble something else is... dumb? Nothing is original then. All creations are inspired from a variety of sources. Nothing is born of a vacuum.

Dunkey where is your sea of thieves review
I think the issue here comes from the limited vocabulary and conceptual ability of the reader/listener just as much as it is a failing of the writer/orator to describe an experience without constantly referring to common tropes (which is actually quite a bit more difficult and requires greater literary/oratory skill).  The amount of times I've seen people say "but is it like x games, I only play those" makes me think that this has become common (especially with "soulslikes" or should we say "blade of darknesslikes" or "zeldalikes") for a reason. People constantly refer to one experience or concept as a point of reference, which is rather essential for quick understanding between two people with shared experience, but it does suggest a lack of ability to describe a new experience or concept solely on its own aspects, and it is virtually impossible for someone who has not shared this experience to understand as well. Given the education standards of society at the moment (and this is not grandstanding, I act very much in the same way) is it surprising we cannot fully describe a new experience or concept without this simplification? I think many people simply don't have the communicative framework to achieve "original" discussion (much like many developers do not have the   I would also say that it doesn't help that game developer's very much rely upon shared experience to entice players. Everyone likes Dark Souls right? So making slightly different Dark Souls will sell well, right? Seems to be developer logic in so many cases. Which is sad because the actual innovation by the developer is often muted, or even lost, while trying to be as close to the source of inspiration as possible. The absolute best (Nioh 1/2, DS 1/2/3, Bloodborne, BoD, The Surge 2, and so on) of the difficult action RPG genre (which is what it is, not "soulslike") all have a similar core concept that is executed in wildly different and innovative ways. From Software is pretty good at the genre now, but that doesn't mean every developer should be seeking to copy them, and it doesn't mean every fan should expect the same game from ever developer. For that way lies the death of innovation!
Comparing new things to old things is okay and good actually

I mean video games, as a medium, is maturing. You can only be so original without taking inspiration from other games. I think original games was more common in the past generation as game developers and players had no idea what they liked and what worked, so they experimented. A lot failed, some succeeded. Honestly, at this point, you could compare any game with any game. Chivalry 2? CoD with swords. Dead Cells? Hollow Knight~esque platformer action with Dark Souls aspects. Pathfinder: Kingmaker? A mixture of 2000's D&D RPG's and Wasteland 3, with some kingdom management aspects.  You never have to make these connections, but after playing videogames for so long, you play a new game and subconsciously make the connection without trying. Even some of the most unique videogames could have connections made (Except for Shadow of Colossus, I actually can't think of anything for that). These reviews take clear elements from other reviews. The elevator pitch is, take another review, and add in the stuff from another review. Fans of other reviews will notice some definite parallels.
I was taught that the ideal elevator pitch for a movie would be to compare it to one or two other movies so the listener could instantly get an idea of what you want the film to be like. For example: "Jaws but with an alligator" or "10,000 BC meets Superbad."

The most recent game I've seen take an original approach was Echo, which incorporated learning AI and you actually have to ration what moves you use to outwit your enemies because they learn sharingan-style and use everything you've shown them next round and the same tactic will never work twice. The reason it failed was because it has a sheer cliff for a difficulty curve and you can very quickly end up in an impossible scenario. And it had an absolutely convoluted pile of trash for story.   It is HARD to be original. It is even harder to be original AND enjoyable, and so many good mechanics have already been discovered and implemented in modern games that it's fatiguing just trying to come up with anything even remotely close.

What is originality truly? I bet if you think of your best example, there's going to be a prior work that inspired this new thing. This is because if an idea is going to work in society, it's drawing inspiration from already existing knowledge. Building on something can still mean something is original. If you then have this new original thing, people are going to compare it to what's known, which is why most (decent) reviews will say it's kind of like *insertpriorworktitle).  Having said that, this is shaping up to be a time of remastering old works, into something that cannot really be called new.

If you have any other hobbies, you would notice that this is quite common; to describe something as to look/smell/feel like another thing in the same universe. For example, a painting that it looks like a Picasso with brush strokes reminiscent of Van Gogh's style. Or a perfume that it smells like perfume Z plus oud. It is one of the easiest and most direct ways of describing something. It helps the receiver understand the reviewer and the object reviewed.
This says more about how poor the reviewers vocabulary is than it does about the apparent lack of originality in games.  They are incapable of talking about a game without comparing them to another game.  If you haven't played any of those older games, you'll have no idea what they are talking about.

This'll get lost in the meme sea but fuck it.  We're at a point in vidya that seems a lot like a similar point that's happened in a lot of things.  Anime, cars, cinema, footwear, furniture, ect.  All of the main concepts and how they synergize or clash are pretty well understood.  At the least, the meta has become stable.  It's not hard to build a game that you know will be at least okay.  There's room in the margins yet, but stepping outside the comfort zone is risky.  And it can fizzle or flop, where your game will sadly be forgotten in the depths of the indie games on Steam regardless of how good or bad or polished it is(Antichamber, Getting Over It With Bennett Foddy, Radiator 2).  But when that risk pays off, you get a TF2 or Dark Souls or BOTW or Minecraft and the rest of the market clamors to fill the niche you created for the next 5-15 years.    So on one hand, I appreciate the indie devs who strike out into the unknown and create a beautiful, passionate game that delivers a unique experience.  And on the other hand, I appreciate a talented studio taking an established concept and polishing it to a shining, silky smooth gem of a game(Witcher 3, Doom 2016/Eternal, Super Mario Sunshine).  It's nice having something new, it's also nice getting a perfect version of something you already like.

Great message
It's psychologically impossible for the human brain come up with completely new ideas. Literally everything is either a solution to a problem, or a mash-up of a bunch of different ideas that already exist. It's no shock that a lot of these ideas that are being mashed together are some of the most well known ones. It's unfair and outrageous to assume game developers are any different. This assumption discredits the creativity beyond the inspiration that is required to bring a game to life from an idea.

Dunk Souls III was so good that someone had to make Dark Souls respecc for dunkey
In fairness that kind of short hand makes it really easy to communicate what kind of game you're going into tho: I *could* spend a full minute trying to describe a game as a top-down action adventure/rpg where the player advances the story by completing a series of dungeons with a heavy emphasis on combat and puzzle solving, but it'd likely just be confusing if you're not at least a little into games design or aren't comfortable or acquainted with language like that - or I could say, "it's a little like a top-down zelda," and get basically the same message across. You're right that at times at can seem a little lazy and far be it from me to pretend gaming journalism isn't capable of being rushed, lazy and shallower than an egg cup, but I think in this case specifically (describing games as similar to other games, yes, even "the Dark Souls of ___" thing even though it was super annoying), what we're seeing isn't because people are getting lazy, or even because games are getting more similar, it's just that over time as new games have come, gamers have developed more concise language to describe games in a way that their friends will understand - we started by inventing names for genres like 'platformers, 'RPGs,' 'FPSs' and I think this is just an extension of that: language to better communicate to our friends what a game feels like to play. I mean hell, speaking of genres, 'metroidvania' is literally just a portmanteau of two games but I don't think anyone would see it as lazy if you described a game as a metroidvania.  Now I get that this video is just poking fun, and I liked it too, I thought it was entertaining. But that being said, it would be remiss of me not to acknowledge what I find to be the greatest flaw in Dunkey's video here: that being that Dunkey is nitpicking and biased, I win, bye bye.
Oddly enough, this might point more to lazy game reviewing as opposed to lazy game designing.    Games are sorted into genres. Genres develop over time by innovating new defining features of the genre.

Shows a lot of the flaws with modern gaming journalism
I'm stunned that you didn't include a single 'Metroidvania'.  But it kind of makes sense to use the shrothand of what other games they're similar to. Call something a 'Souls-like' and you immediately know that it's going to have some combination of third-person perspective with weighty combat that favors skill, a death system that sends you back to a hub and forces you to fight to recover your body, probably some kind of stamina system, and highly limited health recovery that's difficult to use in combat. You COULD say all that, or you could just call it a 'Souls-like'.  That said, there ARE too many games that crib this formula too closely. It's really not that different in spirit from the hundreds of card games which use a standard deck of 52 cards, and often only slightly different rules from other games. I guess the difference there is that you can play basically an unlimited variety of games with a 50 cent deck of cards versus having to pay 20-80 dollars (never mind the outlay for a console or PC) for the new hottest 'Souls-like'.

I mean, this isn't unique to game review and journalism, it's just how media journalism is like. Plenty of movie reviews in the past have said a disaster movie is "jaws but with x animal." this is more a commentary on Games journalism than it is the games themselves. These comparisons are attributed by journalists who are looking for familiar patterns to so they can package each game into a neat little labeled box. If this were a commentary on how games themselves are copying each other then well...that's kind of the ethos of creativity is to use a formula that works and make it your own, there will always be similarities this way but its not theft and laziness as much as it is inspiration and security of investment (video games are a business after all).   If it were so simple for the creatives to come up with completely novel concepts in a timely manner that are also fun to play, well I'm certain everyone would. But to come up with a one-off creative work whether its a movie, game or song it takes a long time because the artist has to plug their work into a constantly evolving zeitgeist. It has to resonate with people on some level for it to be popular. This is why we hear things like "it was so before its time".   This tells us that as the zeitgeist and society evolve, it creates a new blueprint for the next one-off game or movie or piece of art that will truly make an impact. It's because of that that we see so much inspiration drawn from one-offs like BoTW and Dark Souls. Because A) they still resonate with a current audience and B) they're proven to be profitable.  I think we're overdue for the next one-off masterpiece. If anything the way our society has been shaped by the pandemic and politics were going to see an explosion of creativity and art in all mediums.
great video dunkerz. excellent.

I feel that this video is more like a critique towards game critics that abuse comparisons between games -note the word abuse, it's fine to do so every now and then and it can be quite useful -  instead of describing the experience of playing the game that is being reviewed, without the use of external sources. Something that bothered me (and probably shouldn't) is saying that the climbing and stamina mechanics resemble the one in BotW when, in fact, we have seen this before in SotC (perhaps even earlier?), for example. This fact bothers me due to the lack of knowledge, experience, or just plain laziness of the reviewers by choosing to refer to whatever is most recent and has made a breakthrough.  To some extent, I feel that doing this repeatedly is a disservice. As a consumer of a review, I am not interested in what this game resembles, but I am interested in how does it feel to play it and its own merits, despite being similar to an alternative in the market. Since I am not a snowflake, I think that some of you might agree with what I am trying to convey.  Of course, some games are just plain copies, like the one in 1:30.

I don't really get the point of this one, every game draws inspiration from somewhere because developers play games and are clearly influenced by their favorites or things currently popular. We make comparisons to help people quickly better understand the type of game they're getting into using our own experiences, just like with music or movies or whatever, even if sometimes it can be a bit of a reach. It might seem like people reference Dark Souls all the time to the point of absurdity, but maybe it's simply because that game has been so obscenely influential that it actually IS inspiring this many games.

I have been waiting for someone to say it for so long now (unless this isn't the point of this video) All people do is compare game to game. There is no new features, no new gameplay, no new anything. It's all just another game and "heavily inspired". But the problems start when games get called worse versions of the game they were "heavily inspired by". Just play the F'ing game and enjoy it. Notice the influence and move on it's not meant to be your long awaited sequel or be on par with some triple a game you obsessed over.
I feel like after playing BOTW and Genshin Impact, I can safely say that while the initial impression is that Genshin is like BOTW, after the initial part you realize they are not the same. BOTW is far more expansive, with way more world changing tools (tools that help you explore) as well as much harder game play. Genshin has permanent, non breakable weapons, the ability to switch with 4 characters on the fly, elemental reactions, gatcha systems, the list goes on and on. Just because one game has a similar movement system doesnt make it a clone. I feel like reviewers use these comparisons as a way to try to relate the game to the viewer, however as inaccurate as it may be.

I think this is more of a testament to the level of writing in the games journalism scene. All these people seem to have a vocabulary as wide as a fashion supermodel and their whole media experience fits in a tiny Ikea shelf.  It's impossible to create something entirely original because we are shaped by our experience and it inevitably gets into that creation. What makes Dark Souls the Dark Souls of Dark Souls is the remixing of prior game design ideas put into a concise and fun game in almost every aspect. Since journos have a limited time with the games they review, I suspect they're more likely to compare the game to others based on only the most superficial part of the aesthetics that at first glance can seem familiar to something you've played before, instead of their complexity and general game flow, which is how I think most interesting games differentiate themselves. Big companies notice this and that's why many AAA games blow their high poly-count load in the first hour and suck ass every second after that. Thank you for reading my bad opinion.  TLDR: Go play indie games and stay away from youtube reviews.

This video reminds me of the infamous South Park episode where constant references of "Simpsons did it first!'". It's hard to create something truly original when there are so many games that have already come out with every possible element/genre that exists. Just like South Park pointed out where Simpsons have created over 1000 varied episodes, so at some point there would be other tv shows with similar plot/references.
Not to blow your mind or anything but good features of literally any type of media are taken and put into newer takes on experiences that they fit in. This goes for TV, movies, music, games, books, art, basically everything. Not everything can be revolutionary, most great pieces maybe add one or two original things on top of stuff that already works. Art forms are compounding and it becomes more difficult to make anything original unless you want to make something objectively worse than another method. Why try to make a shitty system or idea in place of one that already exists and works perfectly for your purpose? Shocker of a thought, I know. And that's not even considering the basic fact that some ideas aren't possible due to time/money required or technological limitations.
Every game is just ripping off that other game. You know the one, all of em.

This video shows the infancy of videogames as an artform because critical dialogue surrounding works involve continual references to other works. The language for more nuanced, non-referential, remarks has not developed yet. I wonder when games will develop that critical language. Perhaps because of game's complexity as artworks, involving nearly all aspects of other design mediums, references will always be part of the dialogue in this manner? It is an interesting question.

Good video. It shows the lack of care most content and media have for the substance you can find within games. If you can't enjoy a game for the fun or interesting mechanics it has, and instead can only shit on it because it shares similarities to some other games then you're failing to provide a good review, critique, or breakdown of a video game.   If a game has a dark fantasy feel to it and requires repetition, skill, and preparation to succeed; you're right, it is reminiscent of the soul's genre, but that doesn't mean it's bad because of it, and the dismissive attitude that comes along with that shows that most reviewers are just phoning it in. Climbing with a stamina bar is a fun mechanic, and shouldn't be scorned in every other game just because Zelda did it, Shadow of the Colossus did it a long time ago, and plenty of other games have had climbing embedded, the Spiderman games certainly had the urban free roam equivalent, as did Prototype and the Infamous series.

Yes, people will always compare a New Thing to a Thing They Already Know. No matter how actually new or unique that New Thing is. People have to classify and compare things.  And, I'd say that it's really hard to come up with something completely new, unique, never seen before. At this point. Plus, people are inspired by other things, so of course some of that inspiration will be in their own product.  Not to mention, people might not be willing to approach something they are completely unfamiliar with.  I don't know what this video is supposed to prove, honestly. Hell, even if something wasn't intended to be reminiscent of something else, people will find a way to compare it.

I think the title kinda makes it seem likes it's about video games themselves being unoriginal, when it seems more about the critics not being able to talk about games without referencing other things. It brings up some interesting ways in which games as a medium differ from others. As in, filmmakers aren't scrutinised as much for adopting a certain style already seen in other movies, but in games there's always this distinct path from where mechanics and ideas supposedly derive from. Shows just how hard it is to really innovate and separate oneself from the common tendencies of video game development. Now that we're getting to the point that graphical improvement doesn't affect the way games are made as much, it's going to get much harder to be "original", at least for some mainstream games.

It is pretty understandable - a reference to a known comparable game in a review is like a source in an essay. Problem lies in the lengthy stretches of comparison, or very fringe similarities, with no explanations as to what makes the game distinct. That, or leaning the whole review on this crutch, rather than forming a criticism of the game itself by its own merits through analysis.  So, given that most reviews OBVIOUSLY don't do any of that hogwash, the game review circuit is as pristine and useful as ever!!!  Jokes aside, it's funny how even to a micro level this happens - like people analysing mtg cards in saying "This card is just Bolt with downside." etc. etc. Humans love patterns and familiar shit blah blah blah

The games are still original, but it's just human nature to describe similar experiences. Imagine trying to describe a food someone has never eaten. Simultaneously, something doesn't cease to be original because it uses an element of something else. If that were the case, nachos are just mangled tacos.
Fun Fact, you'll never know what an original idea is like until it's already been brought forward, and most of the times it will be first met with hostility, or indifference.  Most of our thoughts aren't original at all, that is what makes us whole as a specie, but occasionally that spark of genius is what brings everyone forward.   In entertainment and art, it's always up to what a creator wants to bring out to the audience: Satoshi Tajiri dreamt the small insects he liked to collect  walking on a cable connecting two gameboys, thus giving him the idea of making the first Pok√©mon game, Miyazaki was amazed by the architectures and designs in Ico, and was mindblown by the western medieval culture, and wanted to replicate that feeling in his games, Miyamoto wanted to convey that feeling of exploring caves outside and making up adventures as a kid, and so on...  When the purpose is exclusively trying to make money, originality is an obstacle and a risk, a gamble that, ironically, bigcorporations aren't willing to make, even if in perspective they have less to lose compared to an indipendent developer/creator.

It's a funny observation, but making comparisons like this makes sense from a reviewer's standpoint. It's a useful shorthand to give your reader a general idea of how the game plays/looks/feels, which you can then expand upon or go into more detail about what makes this game unique. Something like Zelda is such a cornerstone game that using it as an example gives your reader a better idea of what they'll be playing than if you used a vague genre descriptor. Also some games are so clearly inspired by other games that to not point it out would be weird.

Honestly, I think this says a lot more about video game reviewers nowadays, rather than video games. I don't think it's possible anymore to survive in the video game industry and be truly original in every aspect of the game that you're making. I DO think, however, that video game reviewers can write original scripts in their reviews and not obsessively compare everything to other games. How hard is it to describe a battle system without comparing it to Dark Souls? How hard is it to describe exploration without comparing it to Zelda? etc. Just write something original that accurately describes the game without copping out and just comparing it to other games. That's what helps make you a better writer. But no, they just take the easy route.

I don't know if it's really possible to make a truly unique gameplay experience anymore. There's just been so many games made already that it's practically a guarantee that a previous game will already have used the same kind of gameplay loop as upcoming games. Plus for some examples that truly haven't ever been made before, it's either because they rely on technological innovations that haven't been made yet, or the gameplay would in fact be so terrible that nobody wants to seriously make said game.  The only thing you can really make unique is the story context that you frame that gameplay in.

As someone who is almost done with their game dev study and heading into the industry. The majority of pitches will follow this exact format of describing a new concept to familiar elements from existing games. Not a lot of investors nor players will want to have to put in a lot of effort to figure out what your game is and the best way to convey what something is in as little words as possible will always be by relating it to things someone already knows. Otherwise you get something like the first "strand-type" which created a wide range of expectations since it didn't expand on what the game actually was.  Games, and any product for that matter, will always be inspired by pre-existing things. That's just the nature of what ideas are.
So moral of the story is that ‚ÄúDevil may cry‚Äù was the first video game

It can get annoying when they do that type of comparison with video games so often, but I get why it's important to compare the games to give buyers an idea of what they're getting their hands on.

Whilst I agree that gaming reviews have an issue of overmentioning other games to describe a game I do think that because video games are interactive when you are describing a game you also have to convey how the interaction was.Comparing it to a well known game does make it easier for the average consumer to understand what type of game they are about to play.  Now about originality, it's very hard to ask from a game to be 100% original. I don't think that would be possible this days.But a game can be original whilst sharing features with other games.  A good example is death stranding That has a new moving system and it has the stranding system (I think that's what the multiplayer aspect is called) but in the other side it has very basic menus and has a ton of cutscenes
getting a lot of boss baby vibes from this
Idk, I feel like it's such an easy way to describe games when reviewing them to give the reader/watcher some better idea of what to compare the game to. "Zelda-like", "Souls-Like", and "DMC-like" just give such a straightforward quick frame of reference, and it's pretty easy to think "Hey I didn't like Zelda, or I don't like Souls games, so this probably isn't for me". I understand that it gets used very often, which is the point of this video (unless the point is that games just aren't original in which case that's kinda dumb because it's near-impossible to make a completely original game at this point), but as someone who checks into reviews a lot before buying a game it's helpful to me when it's compared to a game I already know about.

Hey dunk... i see what you are trying to achieve here. But... in reality... players dont want originality. People hates seeing something new or try something new. People loves familiar mechanics and familiarity in general. So its actually good for developers that they can reference some existing and succesfull games. And they are doing it on purpose.     Im saying it as game developer who released unique and original game on switch and pc. And it flopped. We did some investigation after some time and verdict was this: people didnt understand our game and couldnt get familiar with it because lack of familiar mechanics. Simply put: making something unique is suicide.     I know it probably may sound frustrating but its what gamers wants... im for sure not going to came with something 100% unique anymore, it costs money, time and its not worth it. Not mentioning that after release i got into very dark place in my life. And there are a lot of people, games, creators like me. A lot of games you never heard about. And they are original... No. Originality is overestimated and generally can be bad for busines. Its sad but its true :(
You have to play it safe even if you could design something completely new (which I doubt you can at this point) the first question people would ask what does it like what games can you compare to? And if you can't they'll just go and buy something familiar because games now are 60-80 dollars and most people don't want to experiment. Our new chair design is nothing like it's predecessors. It is unique in that it combines elements from all its predecessors.
In my opinion, there are so many game genres that even if you start out by trying to make something unique, it ends up being similar to at least one other well known game. This isn't to say you can't have a unique and well thought-out experience, it's just there are so many games being created both in terms of numbers and ideas that it will always remind the player of a previous experience.   For example, one of my favorite games is Hellish Quart and in my opinion it's a very original game, physics based dueling with realism at focus; however even in this scenario you have the instinct to compare it to mortal kombat or tekken for the camera angle and going back in time a bit, bushido blade for the general experience; even though the game is very unique on its own.   Now when you look at games that are designed to be as popular as possible and to achieve as many sales as possible then I believe this problem of unoriginality is exponentially increased, the devs need to eat too and making "hybrid" games from past successful games is one of the most safe and sure methods there is available.   Lastly, I believe this issue also manifests itself in varying areas of interests and hobbies. I mean take a look at different music genres, the originality generally comes from the initial dive into the unknown territory by the artists of creating the genre itself, whereas the following generation of artists listen to the music produced before their time respective to the genre they wish to contribute to and create their own unique experience by combining elements from previous examples and idols. There's still something new being added by the artist but you can understand from which artists inspiration is being drawn from if you're familiar with the genre.

these comparison-laden reviews are lazy and they're a damning evidence of how surface level analysis has become the norm of the industry. however, triple A devs are also part of the problem. they're afraid to experiment with tried and tested gameplay formula so most major releases nowadays are just different combinations of contemporary design trends. in most other creative industries, this sort of stagnation would be identified and rooted out, but for some reason, the majority of game playing audiences and critics actively encourage it. GoW 2018 is a prime example of this. it was almost universally lauded despite being the gameplay equivalent of a somewhat bad gumbo pot. so until something fundamentally changes with this industry, i'd say we're stuck here for a while

I usually think Dunkey is among the most in-tune gaming media guys, but if this is criticism of comparison as a review tool, it's completely off base.  Comparison is nearly inevitable when describing art created by humans who are products of their environment, not to mention an incredibly useful shorthand for describing what a game feels like in a 5-minute review.  Is it overdone a tad?  Maybe, but I don't think these examples alone say anything particularly negative about game reviews or games in general without any argument backing them up.  Also, I'm sure Dunk knows that all art takes inspiration in part from what came before; if Dunkey is trying to say that games have become derivative... that's true of everything in human culture.  We're building off of thousands of years of history, adding some new, but using the old... all the time.    Idk what Dunkey is trying to say here sans argument; this compilation seems completely inoffensive and normal to me.  I do rate him 5/5 though and bought his Snake Nuice, haha so funny.

See, when it shares a few elements, they say "It's like *blank*", but when it outright rips off the core gameplay loop, they have to say "it takes inspiration from *blank*". That way, they're being disingenuous either way!
I mean, that's just how any art is. It's all borrowed ideas from it's predecessors, with their own flair. You could make the same video about music, painting, whatever. Even the most innovative, groundbreaking works of art either intentionally borrow ideas, or will inevitably be compared to past works.

I think this has more to do with the way reviewers try to describe their games than game designers trying to rip off a successful franchise. At this point, when there are so many genres of games, it's only natural that a game is going to receive influence from its predecessors- or at least look like it did. I think the reason game reviewers will use these kinds of comparisons is because it's an easy way to describe the gameplay mechanics of a game- either that or it's just a blatant rip-off, as seen in the video. If it is a good game though, chances are it's still going to have some similarities with other successful titles, since at this point we've seen that there are just some gameplay mechanics/styles that people tend to like more. IGN demonstrates how they can not be taken serious, when they do not even understand the elements that make these games what they are. What does a fast-paced shooter have to do with Dark Souls?! That is mechanically it's diametric opposite. Dark Souls wasn't the first to be hard, it was the first to be hard because of a specific design philosophy. Slow attacks that the player commits to after initiating, aggressive AI, enemy telegraphing, precise hit boxes, punishing amounts of damage, quickly depleting stamina, loss of benefits upon death, etc. If it doesn't even have half of these things, then it isn't like Dark Souls.

I mean I don't quite understand what Dunkey is trying to say with this one exactly. There's a few different possibilities but I don't feel like any of them are clearly it.  *Possibility 1:* Games are unoriginal..? I don't think that's really the case or a problem and even if you thought so this can be applied to pretty much any creative outlet since basically the beginning of time and are definitely not a new thing unique to games just because you're personally noticing it there during your lifetime. Being influenced by things that came before are pretty much human nature and certain things catching on at a large scale and becoming "popular" can obviously be observed in eras of art, music, architecture and so on and independent cultures developed in closed off bubbles influencing others once they come in contact so it's not like a certain type of people during a certain point in time were just naturally drawn to a particular style or genre, no they drew inspiration from what they knew and what people grew to enjoy above other things.  *Possibility 2:* People use popular games to describe other games..? If this is it i don't know why that would be a problem because it evidently has a function in describing what a game is like and many times it's pretty accurate and more efficient than describing it from the ground up as if nothing like it has been done before. People often use the same examples because people are likely to know what that means even if a less well known game might be a closer comparison but additionally it's not unlikely that the most  popular games inspired the developers so they're intentionally like that game. I guess you could make the argument that people rely on it too much instead of describing the mechanics and so on or when they use really wierd combinations or superficial details that don't describe the game well at all. For example I've noticed that people are quick to bring up Breath of the wild whenever there's alot of light green grass but that's about the only similarity. But yeah I don't feel like that was the case here because the clips included weren't comically inaccurate or anything, like I almost don't know how you could talk about Nioh without mentioning Dark Souls.
how about y'all come up with something that's just never been done before
Sometimes I think reviewers kinda fall into the comparison trap. They focus too much on what a game has in common with other titles and not enough on how it deviates from said titles. I cant blame them, i do it too with sometimes, but its becoming all too common to hear a game simply described as a ____-clone and they leave it at that. I think its a little reductive and this video kinda shows that. I mean, I dont know who that was that you sampled Dunkey for that Ashen bit, but man. You see my point right? I wish more reviewers would stop comparing games to each other and focus more ont he individual experiences on offer and wether or not those experiences are worth your time and monetary investment and less on trying to find the perfect collections of games that best compares to the game in question. Rant over. Thanks for the upload Dunkey great work as per usual!

Honestly... I get the point, but I hate people complaining about comparisons. "The Dark Souls of _____" is stupid and cliche, and lots of journalism should be better, but seriously... They're trying to sum up a game in the first 20 seconds of the video before most people click off. Yeah, it's derivative, but they're trying to communicate a feel and experience over video and script. How would you have them describe it?  On the flip side, if it's the games you're complaining about, I also disagree. Outside of the obvious cheap cash grabs based on trends, games taking ideas/ gameplay structure from other games and putting a twist on it is a good thing. The "climb everything/ glider" mechanics from BotW are fantastic, and I'm thrilled to see it everywhere now. It's fun. Yeah, it'll get really worn out eventually. Everything does. That doesn't mean it's inherently a bad thing.  Video is a goof, which is fine. Just my two cents on the matter.

What is happening here is just people trying to describe a game to other people by referring to other games, because that's how people work. - But nobody will ever do a review or explanation without doing so, as they can't just describe a game in its own right. - First of all, they themselves can't help but compare to other games, plus, they wouldn't know what to say if they wouldn't do so. - What makes it worse is that all of them just say the same things, because they've already heard or seen those descriptors before. - Such as the "Uncharted"-reference for "Fallen Order" is only in people's minds because Amy Hennig was once attached. - If that had never been known, people would probably not be as quick to jump to "Uncharted"-comparisons. Just saying; People's way of thinking has been homogenized. That's what a culture is. Gaming-culture in this case.

Donk souls
I think describing a 'new' game by talking about the elements it borrows from existing games should be used to initiate the audience as to the nature of those elements in the 'new' game. But the usage of such references should be a deliberate and conscious choice on the part of the reviewer in order to convey whatever novel ideas the game brings forth, to the consumer. Using references and seemingly idea elements to describe every aspect of a game, especially when doing a critical review is lazy. I know not all games have so much novelty to them in order to do this, but it's on the part of these gaming 'journalists' to highlight the new innovative ideas that a game brings forth while initiating a potential buyer to the familiar fundamentals that the game borrows from established titles.

This video makes me realize how much game media assumes you have played games before. Imagine never having played a game, finding a game revolving around a subject you enjoy (Like Heaven's Vault because of the linguistic aspect of the game), and then the primary descriptors are relating to other games you haven't played.  Most games have a unique twist, but it is an incredibly iterative industry. This video is just making me realize how much linguistic pragmatics are utilized to describe video games to their subculture, instead of utilizing generalizable language to reach an even greater audience.

Describing a games elements using references to other games is totally valid. Yes, it's absolutely overused and often ridiculous, and genres that are portmanteaus of other games are lazy. But it helps get the point across easier than describing the elements themselves. "BOTW climbing" says "you can scale just about anything but have to manage a stamina meter". "Batman combat" says "styled beat-em-up combat with telegraphed counter attacks". We should try to do better than to just use the title of a game, but naming is hard.  It's a colloquial tagging system, which makes sense because so many games aren't constrained to a single genre.

spoileralert: All art is iterative. All of "creation" in general is iterative. Originality comes from the clever use of "old" ideas to create something unique, and these "unique" ideas are used as the building blocks for further creation. its just a shame that people would rather copy what already exists instead of building towards something different.

It's kind of funny, actually. -- now that my rant is over, I agree with this video and its other statement. You can't claim ''this is something new''  and then proceed to name 5 well-known games your current game is heavily drawing inspiration from.  + a little PS in between: if you're 25+, you've already probably experienced most ''new'' things in life. Whether it be in music, books, movies, games etc unless you've simply ''never tried'' some stuff. This matters. I don't see many 15 y.o.'s complaining of lack of innovation. In screenwriting, pitching a movie to a studio, the first line of advice is this, "NEVER TRY TO SAY YOUR MOVIE IS LIKE THIS ONE OVER HERE AND THIS ONE OVER THERE PUT TOGETHER." It's sad that that is how they're marketing games -- there is no such thing as an original thought, everything is derivative of something else in the past, and that's fine; people want to play what they already played but they want it fresh. The shame is in making it blatantly obvious, instead of just saying, "this is our cool game with these cool features," and leave out the comparisons.

Everything sprouts from something older, from Ping-Pong to Pong, Pen and Paper to RPG‚Äôs, and physics for a numerous amount of titles.   Iteration, adaptation and evolution of genres don‚Äôt make them unoriginal; just like how every story borrows foundations from what came before it, so do games, as does all art.
