I somewhat agree and disagree with this video. Companies wanting to make money are obvisouly going to steal ideas that work from other games and I can imagine that it is quite rampant. In that regard, I agree, there must be a lot of blatant stealing. But, I also think games can have similiar aspects and not be stealing or held to a standard as a clone. For example, I don't like to hear that a game is "zelda-like" because there are some similiarities. It is a good way to describe a game by reviewers so the audience know what they are in for. However, "zelda-like" encompasses so many broad aspects. If you are wanting to make a 2D, action RPG, adventure game and you don't want the player to run from the start to the finish, you have to segment areas off. Then to progress the protagonist has to overcome some sort of challenge to progress to the next area. It is only natural then that you use dungeon-esque biomes, bosses, or some sort of puzzle mechanic.   From memory, Zelda may have done that first, but that is because it had been around since the 80's. By default, I don't think that every game that uses this progression is a "zelda-like" game or rip-off. Rant over
Super mario 64 takes heavy inspiration from dark souls 3.

It really is kind of sad that game reviews make so many comparisons, and have basically devolved into saying a game is like X mixed with Y and a hint of Z.  It's convenient because it puts a predefined idea in the viewer's head, but you miss out on any nuances that inevitably make a game unique. UI, atmosphere, presentation, the music, the pacing, the story. You could say that a third person, fantasy RPG that's really hard is like Dark Souls, but what if it's actually very colourful and hits more noble hero story beats? Not so Dark Souls anymore. Actually more like Skyrim in third person.

This is less of a gaming issue and more of a review issue. The way we look at things is we compare them to other things. Games are unique media in that you interact with the game via the game's mechanics and controls. There are only so many ways you can design game mechanics so obviously games are going to draw inspiration from other successful games that did various things well. Yes some games are blatantly ripping off other popular games, but those will never stand the test of time. Breath of the wild is approaching being 5 years old while still being a landmark in the gaming industry. In 4 years is genshin impact even going to be played? What about a decade?

Games are also a inherently risky business (you can make close to nothing), hence the risk adversity. You can also say AAA publishers are corporate scumbags that only like money and dislikes creativity I‚Äôm okay with that explanation as well.  3. Game devs are humans, and humans learn through copying. Monkey see, monkey do. Most game devs are big gamers themselves, and they‚Äôre deeply inspired by the games they love, and it affects how they approach a game.

Originality in dunkey's comment sections:
This is something I've felt passionate about for the past several years. Some game reviewers are so lazy in their actual reviews that they just fill them with comparisons and avoid actual explanations. Comparisons are great as a concise and effective way to describe a game, like amongst friends or even as a short conclusion. But so often, reviewers say stuff like, "It has Zelda-like puzzles" without describing what that means in the game. Does it involve swinging your sword at glowing crystals and shooting eyeballs?   I watched/read a review to learn more about THIS game, can you tell me about THIS game?  Some comparisons, like the Dark Souls comparisons have just become synonymous with difficult. At this point why even compare them at all? Just say the game is difficult. I don't know, this topic gets me too heated.
Ooo new games borrow from old, everything is unoriginal blah blah blah

I don't think anything's wrong with taking ideas from different games and making them into new ones. Even shameless copies and knock offs can be great in their own right. It is a joke that gaming journalism tends to call everything "like dark souls" or make constant ridiculous comparisons, but that's just because it's easier to get into and understand things that are familiar. If they've played dark souls, they could try it out since it's similar. If it plays like a character action game, they'll compare it to the big names in the genre. It helps people find games they'll enjoy; it's why we have entire genres to categorize things. Games that don't have original ideas and mechanics are never inherently bad, that's up to the execution of their inspirations.

I think this is a two-way problem. People are so unwilling to try something new, so being able to pitch a game with "it's like this popular thing" can make it sound a lot more appealing to the average consumer. As a result, every new game has at least a couple of borrowed elements from whatever is popular at the moment (e.g. a battle royale, stamina metre etc.) in order to make it more marketable  In short, the publishers, reviewers and consumers are to blame :/

This is why you should only ever play Dark Souls and Breath of the Wild
Let's be real, there's nothing wrong with this. You gotta remember that this is just an inherent by-product of the way the videogame industry-, hell, it's a by-product of how almost every industry of entertainment works. Which is that somebody has an idea, they look for someone richer to fund that idea, and they proceed to do whatever it takes to make that idea become reality.  It's those last two steps that create this repetitiveness. The people who fund these ideas almost always have no interest in the idea itself, all they want to know is whether it can be made and whether it's worth making. You could have the most original game idea that really pushes the limit of what it means to be a videogame in this world with fresh mechanics humanity has never seen the likes of before and it would not matter a damn bit because if you're not one of the greats like Shigeru Miyamoto or something then a producer has no reason to pump the thousands of dollars you need into a project that for all they know might not be possible and may very well not make back the money even if it is. But that other guy who's pitching a cross between Hades and Breath of the Wild called "Explore the Witch's hut " on the other hand has put forward ideas that we know are possible and we know are popular. So a producer is gonna be much quicker to back an idea.  And that's where the third step comes in. Game designers know that their pitch is more likely to get accepted if they present the core ideas as links to already successful games with some kind of twist, so, in order to make their ideas a reality, they just do exactly that. There's no shame in it, after all, everything "original" is always, _always,_ just based on something already experienced in life plus a twist, so why's it suddenly a problem when it's something experienced in a game plus a twist.  As far as I can tell judging anything based on its originality is just kinda childish and a waste of time. If you go back far enough every "original" idea is just a unique collage of stuff that already exists, and any pothead with time to think can do that but that doesn't mean jack if they don't know how to make a good videogame. It's the ability of the owner of the idea to make it into a genuinely enjoyable experience in the real world that's important and if that can be done well enough then the originality doesn't actually matter.  Also a lot of these were just the fault of the reviewers. Literally any open world with a puzzles is Zelda, any open world with climbing is breath of the wild, and any third person game with difficulty is Dark Souls, it's absurd.
The new 2022 4Runner has four wheels like the 1973 Dodge Charger, a steering wheel in front of the driver's seat like the 2006 Mistubishi Galant, and an engine just like a John Deere riding lawn mower only bigger.

Might be an unpopular take but an "original" title is pretty much non-existent now. Innovations in this oversaturated business have just become "combine x mechanic of y game to a mechanic of b game" rather than be something truly unique, but that's not to say it's bad. Considering most game mechanics that are seen to be fun/challenging/addictive have already been conceptualized or invented, what future game titles just need to do is mix and match these mechanics to make another fun experience and not try to pull another "original" game mechanic from their asses that will flunk.  It's the same argument in music where lyricism can be argued to be unimportant so long as the song "sounds good."

There are relaxing elements to Breathe of the Wild, and you can go out, venture, do anything and feel like you're making a difference in some way. But in Death Stranding, you are. In my mind this is less of a comment on originality in video games and more a comment on how gamers respond to reviewers. If someone says something takes inspiration from X it's the quickest way to draw a picture in your mind about what that game is like. It's lazy on both the reviewers side and the consumer's side, but it works. You can do the same with movies, TV shows DEFINITELY music, or any other media but games come out so thick and fast and we gamers are such dum dums its easiest to make direct comparisons. Not saying there aren't rip offs and "borrowed" elements, but that's par for the course for such a dense media.

I feel like everyone‚Äôs tendency to just compare every game to a couple of better known games stems from the mentality of making more content by putting less effort. Back then when these well known games weren‚Äôt around, game Journalists had to communicate a game‚Äôs structure more straightforward from the ground up. These days people just want to get their content out as soon as possible that instead of trying to deconstruct a game and communicate those pieces to their audiences, they would rather just use a vague and disconnected reference. It‚Äôs a sign that content creators don‚Äôt respect the value of the work they‚Äôre critiquing or the intelligence of their audience. They just want to take a shortcut in writing just to get their vid out first and get their views. With the ever growing consumption and prominence of media outlets and the internet as a whole, journalism becomes more of a commodity and less of a profession.

I'm kinda confused tho, is this video meant to mock the games for their lack of originality or the games journalists for their descriptions of those games? Because in case of the latter, these are just the easiest ways to convey something new to your audience. "New thing is like x and y mixed" is just easy to understand. And if it's mocking a lack of originality in games in general - using previously established mechanics doesn't detract from the remaining originality of a work. Having Zelda climbing or multiple enemies to mow down isn't THE defining factor for any game, it's just part of games at this point. It is quite hard to make something completely fresh at this stage, something that doesn't use any previously established mechanics from other games.

The title of this video: Originality in video games  The point of this video: There is none
So there are two critiques baked into the satire here. One is about game design, and the other is about reviewing.   For the first, game design is an art, and artists either steal from one other or inspireone another, depending on how cynical you're feeling. This is how the creative process works, and as a creative, I think it's healthier to see art as a positive dialectic process rather than a competition for originality. The secret is: nothing is truly original.   For the second part, game comparisons are like book or movie comparisons. If you're worried about wordcount, the fastest way to describe what it's like to play a game is to compare it to other games. Game design lingo is pretty specific and niche, and not useful for a general audience.   Obviously, fast is not good, but try to describe a tv show to someone who wants an accurate description without referencing another show or genre. Without that context, most descriptions feel nondescript and vague.

Daek Soul
I will say that true originality is extremely rare; most "new" ideas are just old ones combined in innovative ways. Reviews of games that do this tend to have the effect of making the game sound like a ripoff of one or more games, but that's because they need something to compare it to so potential buyers know what kind of game they're getting into.  Point is, there's a difference between borrowing cool ideas that work and blatantly ripping something off. Obviously that line is subjective, but it does exist.
That's what you get when idiots calling themselves journalists make everything from a template. Even their voice pitch is almost perfectly same.

As inspiring game developer, it's good to have inspiration from other games. You get to play around with what others have done before and put your own unique twist on aspects of games that you enjoy. The problem is when people set out to make something be something that already exists. It's ok to make a 3rd person action game, as long as you make it have it's own identity.    I understand that the point of the reviewers is to give listeners an idea of what to expect out of a game but sometimes these comments can hurt a game's chance of ever being seen as a unique experience worthy of our time. Anytime I hear "this game is like some other game", it makes the game sound bland.   It's important to remember that "souls-like", "rogue-like", "metroidvania", and such are marketing buzzwords that are meant to stir up hype for a game based on people's opinions of older games. They'll continue to use them until the market has been oversaturated with these types of games and people lose interest.

I think this video is more of pointing out how all these new games are being constantly compared to the most obvious or the most recent popular stuff, instead of anything like a criticisms of them being unable to be 'original'. Notice how the games 'journalists' (I'd assume that's what the other voices in the video other than Dunkey's) couldn't stop themselves from comparing the games they're talking about to other games, in such glaringly shallow and superficial way. While we probably have to sit down and define it properly, I think we all can agree that something like _climbing, stamina, melee combat, etc etc_ are pretty basic and fundamental mechanics in....literally every video games out there. More specific and contextually speaking, some gameplay mechanics are exclusive to certain genres, but within the context of a genre then a mechanic can be perceived as something basic. And yet, these people talked about the games they mentioned as comparison **as if** those games invented all these basic and fundamental gameplay mechanics. And I think that's what this video is actually about.  Or it's just a sh*tpost as usual.

I think this definitely a fault of the consumers, mainstream media and the growing popularity of video games.
I'm 100% on board with the visceral hatred that Dunkey constantly expresses for IGN.
I don't really understand the point of this video? People tend to understand new ideas in reference to old ones. You'll see the same trend in films, paintings, and other kinds of art. To be honest, that's how human creativity in general works: we take things we're familiar with and combine them in unique ways. The idea of "originality" or "innovation" is kind of a myth. Even early games were like this, Miyamoto famously being inspired by personal experiences in the real world for games like Zelda and Pikmin. As the game industry matures, games will naturally start to take inspiration from other games more and more, just as other art forms have done.   So, I don't understand what the criticism is here? Yes, these journalists are describing one game in comparison with another game. And? What's the problem with that? I could understand the criticism that these journalists are making comparisons that don't make sense, at least some of these comparisons are fairly poor, but just as many of these are good comparisons which only help me to understand what these games might be like to play. To me, the real problem here is the inconsistency of how comparison is used; Sometimes, a game's similarity with a pre-existing game is used as praise, other times it is used as a point against the game, describing it as a "knock-off". But the solution to this isn't to stop comparing games to other games. The solution would be to make more thoughtful comparisons, that point out what specifically is similar or different, and whether more clear inspirations are used with care.

This has more to do with how shallow and incompetent game reviewers are than the gaming industry itself. Yes, a lot of games do borrow from other successful games, but that's pretty normal for any piece of media. That's how games and genres evolve overtime, we keep the good ideas and remove the "bad" ideas, well depending on sales and user feedback of course. What reviewers should be focusing on is what makes each game unique, what sets it apart from other games in the same genre, instead of always comparing it to the biggest AAA example of said genre. Further more, it's not like any of the games mentioned here really invented ANY of the concepts that are being used to compare these games.  Dark Souls didn't invent stamina meters, neither did Breath of the Wild, not even when climbing. Yes they obviously popularized these mechanics in recent years but it's just pointless to say a game is a clone because it borrowed one mechanic from a game that people really liked. What reviewers really need is a bigger vocabulary and clearly more gaming experience haha.  And obviously games should strive to take more risks and innovate on new mechanics but you can't really blame big publishers/studios from sticking with what works, gamers support their decision by continuously buying those games, so you can't really blame developers for the problem, it's gamers who vote with their dollars on what mechanics and genres continue to thrive. Indie games try all sorts of unique and original ideas, taking much bigger risks because the budget is so much lower and there aren't 100+ employees whose job depends on the success of a single title.  But while indies may be doing a lot of unique things, very very few people give a $H!T about them. Outside of a few, very few outliers, most indie games barely break a hundred sales. So that's one thing that's always fascinated me. The general consensus is that gamers complain AAA games are too repetitive, shallow and unoriginal, yet those are the only games people buy and play. The only time they buy an indie game is if some streamer/youtuber popularizes it, otherwise indies are $H!T out of luck.
Thank god we will be getting soup type games, hopefully they don‚Äôt get milked to death.

Dark souls takes a lot from Zelda‚Äôs exploration, with some combat of Devil May Cry and Bayonetta, the Challenge of Crash Bandicoot, which Crash was originally inspired by Sonic the Hedgehog, which Sonic was inspired by Super Mario Bros, which originated on the Nintendo Entertainment system, which drew inspiration from the Atari 2600, where that device took the home console inspired by Pong, which took its idea from Physicist William Higinbotham, whom had drawn from the origins of the enigma machine, which was taken from the work of Charles Babbage, whom thought similar to that of Sir Issac Newton, which physics is a derivation of mathematics displayed by Greeks and Egyptians, whom they were inspired by the thinking of Cavemen, who were evolved forms of mammals all the way back in the Cretaceous period, the time after the dinosaurs reigned the earth, which had grown from the life that was in the sea, who were made from archae bacteria, that had seen from chemical reactions and a possible collision of a meteor, that which was born from some far distant galaxy, which galaxies are really parts of a universe, that which was inspired by a Big Bang billions of years ago.

Alternative title: how to be a game journalist
And yet not one strand type game
Pong: It's like a combination of Ping Pong and television. Pong is essentially a Tennis For Two clone, except people can actually play it. Pong was made by the same guys that made Computer Space, a Spacewar clone. If you're not familiar with Spacewar, it's that game loosely based on the Lensman novels that isn't a licensed game because the idea of licensing other IP to make video games hadn't been invented yet.   Now if you want an *original* game, you need to check out Zork. Zork started as a clone of Colossal Cave Adventure, which had a layout copied from an actual real life cave... Okay maybe that's a bad example.  Let's see... Pacman? Yes, Pacman! Totally original! Except Pacman is actually just a reskinned Rally-X.  Space Invaders? Literally just Breakout with guns instead of a ball.   Phantasy Star... No, I mean Final Fantasy... No, I mean Dragon Quest... No, I mean Wizardry... No, I mean Ultima... No, I mean dozens of obscure mainframe games loosely based on 1970s Dungeons & Dragons... No, I mean actual original Dungeons & Dragons supplement for Chainmail... No, I mean Tolkein and Vance and Moorcock... No, I mean thousands of years of legends and folklore and board games...  Never mind. There's no such thing as an original video game idea.
It's more of a lack of originality from reviewers.

Actually not a fan of this video. Whether it‚Äôs movies, games, or books, people use comparisons as short hand all the time, particularly when it comes to recommendations. It is perfectly normal for someone to say ‚Äúoh if you like Ray Bradbury then you might like the imagery of this book‚Äù etc etc. Game reviews are typically trying to give consumers a sense of whether a game suits their interest and comparisons are an easy way to do that. Can it be lazy? Sometimes Yeah. Can it be helpful? Sometimes Yes.   I really don‚Äôt like this approach of clipping people‚Äôs work out of context. It‚Äôs just not respectful and often isn‚Äôt representative of someone‚Äôs perspective. It‚Äôs lazy. Get why Dunky might get frustrated by this pattern but I just think it‚Äôs a perfectly fine and normal thing that‚Äôs use is more or less helpful depending on the context.  PLUS sometimes it‚Äôs just true video games are drawing ideas from one another like any other piece of media. Intertextuality is just a fact of culture

But Dunkey, this is present in all forms of art. You always have the innovators, the classics, the groundbreaking stuff that influences whole generations and starts movements inside the medium. You could say that Metallica invented thrash metal, but they were influenced by Motorhead who where influenced by some punk band who were influenced by the Beatles who were influenced by traditional blues etc. All art forms are a bunch of stolen ideas thrown together, I think it's in the execution where you must shine above the rest.

Honestly, while it's not necessarily wrong to see comparisons in games, the whole 'this game is basically this game but with a twist' critique really kinda disrespects the game being criticized. It especially gets messy when you go "This game is like Bayonetta' and then you look at the reviews for Bayonetta and it has lines like 'Bayonetta is like Dark Souls but faster' then you see the reviews for Dark Souls and it has a line that goes 'Dark Souls is like the Legend Of Zelda: Twilight Princess but much harder'. It's just an unending, hellish spiral.
Ookay, dunk. I've been loving every single vid of yours since you've started this channel, but THIS video is the one video I don't fully agree with.  I get what you're trying to emphasize on the video, but I also see some of key issues with your argument. First, your complaints around the lack of originality doesn‚Äôt make sense to me. For example, if you take your argument on originality and put it in contexts of art or music, it simply doesn‚Äôt make sense. No medium can be completely original, and that‚Äôs not necessarily a bad thing. ‚ÄúNon-original‚Äù things can still inspire and help create amazing new experiences. So how is video game different from this concept? How can video games be completely unique from its predecessors? I feel like the main objective of new games is to progress from past gaming experiences, and that will inherently mean that new games will have inspirations from previous games and innovations. And to add on, your complaint might be more around the actual execution from these game studios that may have the right set of influences from previous games but screwed up on making a cool new experience. But at that point, I feel like it deviates a bit from your argument on the originality of the game but rather about the technicalities  And your collection of clips on game comparisons being ‚Äúelevator pitches‚Äù‚Äî they‚Äôre exactly that. They‚Äôre general marketing comparisons that are made to draw appeal to the mass audience. So when a game review video adds these ‚Äúlike Zelda‚Äù comparisons, I feel like the main intention there is to sell and simplify, not to make an actual astute commentary on the game. At the end of the day, the game needs to sell for them to make more (possibly more ‚Äúoriginal‚Äù) games. So I feel like the beef you have with this aspect of the originality thing may root more from the game reviewers who actually make these comparisons rather than the actual games. I‚Äôm honestly not sure.
I guess it doesn‚Äôt quite count since it was a text review, but I‚Äôm surprised there was no mention at all of the GamesRadar review comparing Crash N. Sane Trilogy to Dark Souls, as if Dark Souls came out before the original Crash games.

This is a symptom of the game industry's awful habit of using mechanics instead of feeling and concept to define genres. You don't call all sci-fi horror movies "Alien-likes" or all epic fantasy "Rings-like", you can have genre-defining entertainment without LITERALLY using it as a nickname for the genre. A lot of game genre also just has terribly vague definitions, like "RPG" or "MOBA". Game industry really needs to set up a better system for describing games, and honestly, I also hope Devs invent some new types of combat instead of copying Dark Souls, I'm never buying any game with dodge-rolls again, I'm tired of the same shit.
I can see the devs took a lot of inspiration from pong, maybe even a little bit of tetris in the way the scoring system works

In Game Critics, Dunkey said that because critics were playing the most recent games constantly, their opinions were mostly based on these new games and I think that this video is an illustration of that idea.
I'm wrapping up a game dev degree, cuz i was set down a marketing path and that was boring as fuck. but this is actually just how i've experienced indie dev cycles. hardly anyone seems to be able to come up with or discuss gameplay elements or design concepts without describing it in terms of games that have come before (probably because evoking other games is the only way management and investors can be given a baseline as to how potentially profitable your idea is). it gets to the point where even if you have an idea for a mechanic or design concept that isn't easily reminiscent of other designs and concepts, you still have to find a way to shoehorn the concept into analogies of other games. do you have any idea how many times i've been involved with a design process that had every single element tied to some element of overwatches design?! i've been involved with creating RACING games that somehow need inspiration from doomfist's heavy attacks
This is like the viva pinata of game journalism

It‚Äôs one part bad writing on the journalist side, like find a better way to describe a game. But tropes and general design choices come around all the time. Devil May Cry, Dark Souls, Breath Of The Wild, they all introduced design choices and a style for the genre and those avenues are gonna be re-explored a lot cuz they work and it‚Äôs safe to use what works. It‚Äôs a large collective ladder of good design that grows with experimentation, if every aspect of every game was different and new not only would it take forever to make a game but the majority of them would either suck or just be unplayable, but a lil experimentation is real good

PC gaming really stole console gaming's stuff with the whole "pressing buttons" thing.   In fact, it can be traced back to 24000BC when CaveBot Knack first pushed a round pebble into some wet clay, which forced some rancid bubbles out through the surface of the clay with a fart noise. All sources indicate that CaveBot Knack  laughed at this for 26013 years straight, after which he exclaimed "I like that!" in an almost patronisingly obvious tone. This led directly to Knack inventing the modern button, and Knack for PS5 was released the very next day thanks to his incredibly detailed work. Thanks Knack!!

I get the point Dunkey is trying to make but honestly, I don't see the issue here. Sure, some game reviewers are genuinely awful at their jobs and have no ability to review something without comparing it to something else but for the most part you see this large amount of comparing because gaming as an art form has not finished maturing. We are where movies were in the 1920's, largely gimmicks people enjoyed for the baseline experience they provided, i.e. "moving picture", rather than something enjoyed specifically for it's content.   This is because we are still in the midst of the technology maturing, we are still watching gaming grow and evolve and innovate and make new standards for others to be compared to. This is just the consequence of the art form primarily being staged by technology, you need to compare a game to others games because that's simply the only reference point many people will have to certain mechanics. Why spend the time to explain what a combo system is or how a certain hack and slash gameplay feels when it literally is just copying Devil May Cry to a tee and anyone who has played both can tell? If anything, the comparison allows you to further define the combat because it lets you focus on the differences and gets the similarities out of the way immediately.   Of course this is always used as a crutch by bad writers, and the reason for the multitude of bad gaming reviewers is also due to the lack of maturity in the art form. But for the most part these comparisons happen in any art-form, specifically with art that is clearly derivative. Art doesn't exist in a bubble, influences can be obvious and there's really nothing wrong with discussing them plainly.
All games are just heavily inspired from Pong.

I don't think there's anything inherently wrong with making comparisons to other games when reviewing or analyzing a game, especially if the games are contemporaries. A lot of these examples definitely stray from "fair comparison" into "its a lot like this game met this game and this game and then these games combined to kind of make this little element that's like this game." By the end of that tangent you've hit so many layers of abstraction, you've lost the ability to draw any coherent commentary forward.

Correction: "Originality in Games Journalism"
In the gametech course at university of utrecht, we had to pitch our games without the use of prior games. It was actually easy as you can often just use genres to explain what your game is about. For example, "Scribblenauts is a sidescrolling adventure game where you can talk to NPCs, type words to change the gameworld so as to spawn or modify things to make them happy!"  The whole idea of not referencing other games is so that no knowledge about prior games is needed and you're not stuck in rigid thinking.

Yeah, well, all art is derivative. Sorry, but it's true. All ideas come from somewhere and everyone's imagination is a regurgitation of what they take in.   That isn't to say striving for originality is pointless. But originality isn't about making something complicated and unheard of so much as it's about remixing what fundamentally works to be fresh again. This is where theory in every art form comes from. Do what works and be risky and challenging in smaller ways as a sort of icing on the cake. You don't have to reinvent the wheel, you just have to make it seem cool again.

Dark Souls is released and becomes succesful by having a mostly 6th generation gameplay design and approach. Everyone starts to copy Dark Souls, just because, not understanding why. Another issue is the fact that games "journalists" still have jobs.
Obviously there won't be any game that's 100% unique (aside from the very first game of its genre), but there's a point where comparing it to those similar games is doing it a disservice. When it's blatant like how Genshin Impact clearly takes a lot of inspiration from Breath of the Wild, you don't have to compare every game with gliding to Breath of the Wild. Like don't say "Just Cause" is like Breath of the Wild only because you can glide around with a parachute. The other problem is, when a game is unique enough to stand out, you can be setting it up for failure by comparing it to other games. By saying the game is like Zelda or God of War, whatever, then some people who aren't fans of what it's being compared to will steer clear of the game, while others might expect it to be too similar to those games and be disappointed. I also definitely see it as a red flag if the developers are saying "our game is similar to these other games" because that is actually telling me "we've just ripped off all these games without adding anything new or unique."

While I can kind of get the point of this, that the quality of gaming journalism has diminished, this isn't exactly a new thing in gaming journalism or other review media based journalism such as say film or music. Comparisons are drawn because it's quick, it's easy to do and immediately flagpoles to consumers the qualities of the product they're about to consume. It's a no brainer. There's no 100 percent original, uninfluenced thing.   Journalists commenting on the fact other games share similarities because they're literally influenced by another game is... not bad journalism? The Genshin Impact one in particular - it's literally a gacha weeaboo version of Breath of the Wild.

I don't get the underlying argument or critique. The fact that these reviewers are comparing the games to other games is good - it makes a reference to something that might be familiar to you, and gives you a clearer picture of what's in the game. The fact that these games borrow from past games is extremely normal and not worth bashing. So what exactly is the message here?

I think the great thing about video games today is that every tiny idea will be copied and threshed out a million times before it dies. There's a lot of repetition, but the mechanics that we love are carried over to other video games where they can be implemented in a slightly different way opening new possibilities for game play and storytelling. I don't mind that all video games are copies of each other. For me the problem comes when developers recycle mechanics and ideas in order to produce a game to meet a deadline, or purely for profit. Rather than spend time and money innovating and creating a compelling game, they recycle mechanics and ideas, then polish it in a marketable way. Money bad, video game fun, recycle is allowed

You can almost always point to a piece of entertainment and say that it reminds you of this or draws inspiration from that. This isn't bad outside of obvious cash grab ripoffs.

The ability to point out similarities among game reviews does not imply there is anything wrong in reviewing games in this way.  Saying a game has fighting mechanics similar to Dark Souls and exploration similar to Uncharted can be a lot more easy to understand than describing each of these games' mechanics in great detail. It's an easily digestible way to explain how a game functions, feels, and plays to gamers who have played or even seen gameplay of those previous games.  I don't see anything wrong with game reviewers using these comparisons.

You know, I don't think that what people dislike is generally being unoriginal, I think this is something that they're convinced they don't like because it keeps getting parroted. I think it's fine to be unoriginal, I think many things are totally derivative and function well as valuable, standalone works in their own right. I think what people really want above originality is authenticity, and that is something that, in the games industry, is in relatively short supply. Obviously you still have to do al the other things that make a game good, but if it's not authentic, if it's not genuine, then it just feels uninspired, there's not going to be thought put into why something else was good.

Nothing's original anymore. It's just who can profit the most off other people's ideas
One those dudes said "there's nothing like this game..... except these games right here"
Because it's a massive industry, and every video game is a massive investment. Like cinema, the only way to hedge your huge investments is to base it on what has been profitable in the past. That's quite literally it. There are plenty of people wanting to make wildly experimental games, but most of the time you'll hear nothing of them. There is not a dearth in "originality," it's just the nature of Entertainment/Art in capitalism.

Idk man, its just easy to convey the sense of something to someone by comparing it to something they already know. I'm guessing your point is that you're tired of so many new games being like dark souls and BOTW, but every new game is copying other games. It's become exponentially harder to be original in most art forms and media in the 21st century because almost everyone has access to almost everything ever made, so it's nearly impossible to create something free from influence to produce something original. Like try making an entirely new sport or a new type of clothing, it'll still be a lot like something we already know. And the last "original" game was Death Stranding, a weird movie with 40+ hours of mailman simulator in between scenes. Shooters will have a shooty thing, platformers will have some way to platform, Nintendo games will have Nintendo stuff, etc.  And people naturally categorize things to make them easier to understand (literally why stereotypes exist and are so hard to unlearn), so when they say it's blank mixed with blank, that's just how our brains work. If the games journalists didn't mention the inspirations, you'd then be mad that they didn't call out the blatant similarities. They probably shouldn't open with the comparisons, but start with introducing the world and mechanics of the game.

Honestly, whilst I appreciate there is humour in stitching it all together, ultimately it seems like a jab at standing on the shoulders of giants. That I'm not a fan of, the number of games released every year that aren't clearly derivative of another game is usually 0, and on the rare year someone truly breaks new ground in the medium, it's usually shit like all first iterations of things.  Describing games in terms of other games is far more compact and comprehensible than trying to reinvent the wheel of adjectives, and even if you do, folks will just say "oh, so like dark souls", being upfront about it is best for everyone.  Celeste, BotW, Dark Souls, none of these games are actually very original if you know where to look, let's be less concerned on original, and more concerned on quality of execution.

"So is the problem with journalists being so inept they can only describe games with other games, or developers being so lazy they only make games with mechanics form other games?" "Yes."
This video is funny and all, but I really think this is a conversation that needs more traction. The market for, not just games, all media has become oversaturated. Every game developer/publisher is chasing after the coat tails of the person in front of them, and in turn is stagnating the creativeness of the medium. This is what has the mobile market so messed up, and what has triple A companies losing out to indie developers. Everyone is trying to play it safe to make money, instead of expressing creativity and creating unique products. God look at the MMO market and WoW. This in turn is bleeding into the consumer base. We're becoming desensitized to this, and leaping at every little difference and defending companies because "no other game is combining a, b, AND c". People have become so jaded towards change, and it's sad. Everything is rehashed something else.   What makes games like BotW, as an example, so huge isn't that "oh you can climb stuff, stamina, and cooking". It's because it challenged its own IP and took a huge risk in change of its design to create something that felt unique. All these companies keep, seemingly, looking at its individual parts and ignoring the context that put these well received games where they are today.  Argument I keep seeing, "Oh but the graphics are cleaner in this rehashed game".. Upgraded graphics are the easy way out of this exact problem. No one can come up with a unique idea, so lets just cram time and money into making this hair blow in the wind and sweat glisten on the skin. And the general consumer base eats that shit up. Blows my mind. Graphics didn't make Undertale such a huge hit. Graphics don't make Kenshi one of the top rated games on steam. In the same way that climbing doesnt make BotW so highly rated. Creative freedom, and player agency. Something companies have continually failed to capture as a whole.  Shit, this is why Minecraft and Skyrim is still so popular 100 years after they came out.
3rd person with dodge system = dark souls
Game: *breathes*  "Playing this game has elements of Breath of the Wild with Dark Souls difficulty"
People overrate originality and overestimate how creative you need to be to make an interesting product.  Observing the world around us, having personal experiences, and sharing ideas with people, has always been the root of creativity. Its about constructively sharing a common experience with a personal twist.  There's no need to reinvent the wheel every time. You dont criticize pasta alfredo because "its just pasta marina with a different sauce". Heck, why go that far. Even a single dish like pasta marina can be made with a different spice blend, a different cooking method, different cooking timing even and the experience can still be considered fresh. Not every creation needs to reinvent the wheel.  Basically, if you always try to buy the latest iPhone but think every game is a knock off of zelda or dark souls you clearly not thinking things through.

This video took inspiration from dark souls
Here's the irony: nobody has really copied Dark Souls 1. Even FromSoft failed miserably to capture it in their own sequels. What gets copied is things like difficult bosses requiring fairly precise timing of block/dodge/parry.. or a bleak, literally dark world. But those alone aren't really what made DS great, nor are they even the most important bits. DS set a mood and tone with an interesting and detailed world and it made an incredibly cohesive, interconnected world that made palpable, it felt real.. not like a patch of "levels" with load screen gates.   Nobody ever copied this because it is so difficult. Even FromSoft either failed or stopped trying (so far).
So every game is either a rip off of Dark souls, zelda or devil may cry
Everything is derivative, but this is more of a critique of the reviewers than the games themselves.

The way I would describe this phenomenon, before even watching this video, is while these high end games set a standard, its not really them copying directly or stealing game mechanics, it's  them taking what works so they can try an progress and entirely unique story to make for a different experience.  Them saying "it's like this," is to associate the gameplay with quality.   While it might get repetitive, this just means it's all the better, when new games hit that gold mine of originality and niche mechanics.  Subnautica and Among us come to mind, which is why I say people should never sleep on indie developers.  It doesn't make those other games bad, it could be considered them progressing the genre with those unique combinations, and seeing what innovations can be made.

There are so many genre-defining games in our minds now thanks to 40 years of gaming history, so it's hard not to make comparisons.  Devs use good ideas from other games because they're good ideas, that's normal.  The problem now is how to straddle the line between inspiration/homage and a complete knockoff.  New ideas are rare, so we must treasure them even if they're bad.  Some games will create new templates to emulate, and some will be Death Stranding.  Now every dev knows to never do Death Stranding again.  See?  Progress.

the dark souls of strand type games
The problem lies not with the "unoriginality" of the games, but rather the "unoriginality" of those reviewing them. Reviewers and critics fixate so much on what they already know instead of what new experiences these separate creations can present them with. There are only so many "good" game mechanics/styles that can exist anyway so why force developers to tread new ground and make potentially lesser games for the sake of being "original" rather than just looking at their creations as separate works and giving them their own fair and unbiased chances?  Literally everything in life is derivative.  Every thought or idea a person can have is influenced by what happens around them and/or what they've experienced before. Why not simply try to enjoy the subtle differences rather than target and label what you've seen before as "unoriginal" or "overdone"? Every day new people are born that have had *no* exposure to the things we might find bland or cliche and to them these "unoriginal" works could be their first introduction to the very same mechanics and stories that we ourselves grew to love so much that we drove ourselves to become jaded cynics through overexposure.

OK but literally every art form draws inspiration from something else. Originality manifests in combining styles and concepts found elsewhere in such a way that the resulting art seems wildly different. Even the first cave drawings were of things early hominids have seen before.   On that note there is nothing wrong with comparing similar games to each other. Pathologic is a very original game IMO but it's not like the concepts, themes, or gameplay can't be found in anything else. When I talk about the game to other people I might also talk about Soma, or Planescape, or existentialist literature like waiting for godot in order to describe it. That doesn't necessarily mean that Pathologic isn't also itself unique.

Alright I'm gonna be that one numbskull here: I don't really think being original is possible since a LOT has been done and inspirations are up the wazoo. Well, I can't agree that this is a bad thing (that's the tone I understood). Every idea is just a remix of known things.  Even Pong could have been best described as "It's like tennis" to people who don't know the game.   Building that kind of connection works best to convince someone to play a game/buy a thing. Because when we humans want to experience something, we want to have some kind of anchor to decide, "Will I like it or not?". Oh, I know tennis, maybe I'd like Pong too." Or today, "Oh, I like Dark Souls, maybe I'll like that game too."   And I'm of the opinion that you can't set a very good anchor with a genre like action-adventure, shooter, racing game, etc. either. We're so spoiled with so many video games that we only want to spend our time on things where we know we'll like them.   Still, the editing was good and the fact that the journalists used many of the same games as reference is pretty funny xD Some more variation would be good.

I think a more appropriate title for this video is "game journalists using limited vernacular". There is not a single game that is 100% original. Art is inherently iterative since art is created by people who have ideas they want to share. These ideas are based off of their own experiences. Their experiences include what they think of others' art and how it affects them. If a developer today grew up playing Mario or Shadow of the Colossus or Halo or whatever, there's a good chance they really care about those pieces of art and it influenced their worldview, what matters to them, and what they want to create.  But yeah, game journalists are just bad at not repeating the same things over and over. That's my takeaway from this video.

This isn't a problem with the lack of originality but time constraints and budgeting. Developers say stuff like this to tell you what their independent game is like to attract already established large fanbases. It's easier and cheaper than trying to sell you an original idea which is harder to do. If a 3rd person game came out that was fast paced and hack and slash it would be easier to just say it's similar to DMC rather than spend 10 minutes trying to explain the gameplay concepts.  People's ears don't twitch when they hear original ideas. They twitch when they hear familiar names of titles they already like.  Edit-- On second thought this video might be poking fun at journalist's inability to actually critique games and calling all of them copy-cats.

When it comes to art in general, "originality" does not mean "something that hasn't been done". Originality means taking something, or multiple things, and making it your own by changing enough to make it stand apart from what inspired it.  It is NOT a negative thing to draw inspiration, rather it is impossible not to. SO don't hold it against games or artists unless they actually blatantly copy artwork and coding/animation
We all know Breath of the Wild invented Stamina bars and cel shading and Dark Souls invented difficulty and dodging mechanics

To be fair... All artists draw inspiration from their predecessors.  "No man is an island"- John Donne  And to paraphrase Descartes, there is no such thing as imagination in a vacuum. Everything we imagine is an amalgamation of thoughts and prior experiences. Can't imagine a color that doesn't exist.  That said, it would be nice to see more art in general take more risks and break tropes and cliches... But understandably more financial risk.

I can't decipher the purpose of this video. Is it just meant to be mocking the overuse of reviewers using comparisons? In that case I kind of get it; they're definitely overused and can be a lazy tool, but they can also be pretty valuable when making legit comparisons. Or is it supposed to be trashing the actual lack of originality in games? Because like...yeah, that's how any art form works. When a medium's been around for decades or centuries, it's always going to become nigh-impossible to create anything that's truly 100% unique- there's only so much you can do with the tools of the art form, and you're always going to be drawing inspiration and influence (whether consciously or subconsciously) from the previous  examples you've experienced.

Okay, so every game is either Zelda or Dark Souls.
So, fun fact; humans as a species are actually really bad at coming up with new ideas. Most "new ideas" are usually just multiple old ideas combined together in some way. We as a species are weird in that we're kind of built to recycle ideas, yet we also crave fresh and new ideas. Now when someone says something like "I wish X was more original" I think what they want is that when something tends to fall into a pattern (say, a game following a recent trend or a game journalist comparing a new game to several older games), rather than a new idea,  is for someone to break the mold and do something different. Or in other words, they're all going right so I'll go left. The challenge in this line of thought is to make a different experience both a good experience and relevant thematically to the times in which it is released.  Thank you for coming to my Ted Talk.

I might be in the minority on this, but I don't really mind constant comparisons. Obviously entire games shouldn't be placed under the "Zelda-like" or "Souls-like" banner unless obviously taking from that formula (i.e. Immortals Fenyx Rising and all of the FromSoftware games), but comparing individual mechanics to other games is actually pretty helpful when I'm looking for new games to play.

I think some people are also missing the point a bit, and perhaps I am too however. This is just as much a critique on journalism as it is on gaming. Everything is inspired by something, and you can draw roots of some of the best video games ever to something preceding it. Hardly anything is truly original, but the comparison strings in journalism really bleed any semblance of originality out of some actually original new concepts for games. When you take a games comparisons in a vacuum without actually diving into the new mechanics or anything it does new and only focusing on what it does similar or the same you get what this video is.
Maybe it's just the reviewers who are unoriginal, but then again, I just copied that comment from Dark Souls.

Wow, this video felt a lot longer than 3:35 to me.  And I gotta admit, it did an excellent job of illustrating why gaming hasn't been truly exciting in a very long time. Or if they manage to push through and build something truly original and excellent, other studios just take what they did, and it isn't long before it's all just part of the same soup that gets poured into every gamer's bowl.

For what it's worth - while this kind of thing shows how hilariously pathetic mainstream game journalism (or all journalism tbh) is, there is a reason. The widespread obsession with originality and "progress" means we often forget how incredibly important iteration is to art. The constant Dark Souls comparisons are a reflection of just how important that game is - because a lot of stuff has taken inspiration from it.

"this thing is kinda like this other thing" is bad now, i guess
I mean, our brains are definitely pattern seeking, and a lazy yet effective way to get across what something is like is comparing it to something else that's more popular and saying "like that thing that exists!"  Most of these cases it's very likely that the game was in development well before the game that it's being compared to actually released so saying they took inspiration from is generally a very unsafe bet without a direct quote from someone on staff confirming it.  On the other hand entire generas are built on comparing the game to other games that exist Roguelike/Roguelite Soulslike/Soulsborne, Metroidvania, they're comparing the game to other things that already exist and people just know what they mean well enough to not have to question it, and to be fair, if you had to describe that a game has procedurally generated levels, an upgrade system as you progress through the game, and having death factor into gameplay in a unique way (often by soft resetting the game), why would you want to, and would it be harder to explain what that all means than say "It's a roguelike!"  But to run counter to what I just said calling a game like Ratchet and Clank because it has easy 3rd person platforming is weak as hell, that series was all about the weird weapons and the cool levels just facilitated playing with them in new ways while giving you the sense of making progress.
It's official, dark souls came before the concept of existence
The amazing thing is, everyone's ripping off Zelda, but the game designer of Zelda always says that he takes inspiration from real life.   It's almost like you get a better product if you draw inspiration from something that has more content, like real life, so that way you don't end up making the same game as everyone else over and over again.

Ok... But is this a negative?
Taking inspiration in something is normal. Everything around us ( that is the most noticeable in art and design fields ; architecture, fashion, painting, movies etc and video games represent many of these mediums combined) is a giant and repetitive loop where ideas are recycled. We pick and chose different traits, from a trivial detail to a vital element, and apply it to a new piece of work. There‚Äôs nothing wrong with that. Nothing is truly original to begin with. So guys relax and enjoy the damn games !  ‚ÄúNothing is lost, nothing is created, everything is transformed‚Äù - Lavoisier

I can remember the 80's and 90's 8 and 16 bit eras where everyone was so excited and speculative about the future of gaming, and everyone had dozens of crazy creative ideas for games and kinds of games that could be done with just a little bit more small sized computing power. Then.... None of it happened. GTA 3, halo 1, the first call of duty were the last games ever made sometimes. Post PS2 era, nothing new and worthwhile as far as couldn't miss gaming. I mean, maybe shadow over Mordor... But you really have to think for examples like that. Even in ps1 and 2 times you could pick 6 random games and 4 would be something that you never imagined before. Audio USE has not improved past ps1 shadow tower. No more additional game memory has been used for full realizing anything, just making it more expansive. The retro movement was only half realized by going back to what worked and doing it "more" or in the way they wished they could have done it back then, but then stalls out half way in realizing that even.

Idk if this a commentary on the lack of originality in video games, or IGN's shitty reporting of them.
There's a lot of "the dark souls of" in recent game reviews, but before that, and even now still, any time we call a game a roguelike we're saying that it's like Rogue (1980). As more video games are created, we'll have a larger pool to draw comparisons from, and naturally hear more expressions like this. While they're useful for creating a quick introductory impression, it would be nice to hear more about what the goal of the games are, rather than "Solitaire is the Mystery Dungeon of card games" or "Civilization is the Chess of simulation games."

I feel like the messaging here is kind of mixed. I dont like the notion of "there are no more original ideas" because it not only presumes originality equaling quality, but also that mash up ideas dont count as original, or that media is inherently lesser for being built from a foundation, which is basically just punishing people for being born late.   But i also understand that the larger point of this video is most likely that major publications have trouble articulating their thoughts on games without directly comparing them to other things, sometimes without merit (see the ever present dark souls comparisons.) Still, while i get that can be reductive, and imply a game to be a knockoff, theres also no point in saying "a 3d hack in slash with puzzle elements and contextual button prompts" when I can say "its like God of War, but" and get the message across much more efficiently. I think the reason we see all these comparisons being made is that it's just kind of a human way of describing things rather than a lack of originality. Like when describing how something new tastes you're going to compare it to something that it doesn't necessarily taste like. I know this is a bad example but if you've never had cereal before you'll probably compare it to bread or something. Also there's stuff like when 1st person shooters came out, they kept being called doom clones until being recognised as its own genre.
In all seriousness, we're past the point of entirely new experiences. Everything is going to be based on something else, even if it does so in fresh and unique ways.

I personally think that comparing a new game with other beloved ones is a useful technique in reviews so the audience can sorta imagine what the game feels like without having played it.  But in the examples that dunkey shows here there are several issues that should be avoided: 1) When a reviewer says that a game is unique and "like no other" and then immediately compares it to other similar games (Which, granted, can be a good argument if you're saying the combined mechanics of several games can feel like a unique experience but you gotta be careful when you say that) 2) When a reviewer uses way too many examples to describe a game. Just one or two are fine, but five or six is just too much. It kinda muddles the identity of the game you're reviewing and makes it sound like a cheap knockoff of other games. 3) When a reviewer mentions the similarities to other games as a good thing...and then knocks a few points off the final score for being "derivative"  I feel like it's important to clarify this because dunkey's fans can be quite stubborn and take his videos at face value. I'm pretty sure dunkey himself has nothing against this technique itself, but thought it was funny/important to show some examples of game reviewers using it wrong and/or overusing it.  (Also, I was surprised when I saw that old review of God of War 1 saying it took after DMC1 and Onimusha 1. Like, it was something that game reviewers had been doing since forever. And it's especially hilarious because GOW1 would eventually end up being used to describe other games that were inspired by it in the future...)

I mean this is all just a common persuasion tactic. Reviewers, marketers, etc try and use references that may relate to a target audience.

There‚Äôs no such thing as a completely original game. Even if you were to completely disregard all possible sources of inspiration, it would be impossible (or nearly impossible) to make something that has no resemblance to any other game. This has more to do with the limits of the medium than it does with originality / lack of originality on the part of creators. Gotta say, I kinda disagree with this idea. Saying a game is like other games in reviews can often be a shorthand for readers to quickly identify what kind of game the reviewer is talking about, especially with the amount of games that borrow a lot from dark souls. And I don't think taking a few things from a successful game it's necessarily an issue, after all creativity can also be shown by taking an stablished mechanic and putting a twist on it.

I like the video, but lets not confuse ideas: You can make a game original as much as you want, you will always find your basic gameplay/mechanics/influences based on other games that came prior, this doesn't take away originality. And yes you can make a completely never made before game (baba is you for example), but many people would find it confusing or unfamiliar. Like writing a story, i can try to be original as i want but i need to use words that everyone comprehends in an order that, in the end, will make sense. And if i try to write my original story, i will in any case take ispiration from somewhere.  I think i made my point, also, let's not forget that after something happens in human history and it is given a name, everything after it comes to term with it. A king got stabbed? Do you remember about julius caesar? They gave them armbands? Do you remember the jews and the genocides? Have you made a place to sit out of wood and pillows and called it sofa? Like a big comfy chair?  EVERYTHING will be paragonated to something that is considered common knowledge
It's not the originality problem we have, it's the developer take on the genre, often devs do the same thing over and over without adding something new.

Let's be honest here, games are like any other artistic medium. Eventually human originality runs out and you start to run into repetition. I can't remember who made the argument for this but basically it states that people haven't been "composing" original music since the days of Bach. Because ultimately people now get influenced by a bunch of different things and come up with this sort of melting pot of influences. So, ultimately, people have been ripping each other off in music since those Bach days. The people who are most original still win though. Then again, in pop music you basically have the same chords repeating so much that there's even lawsuits flying around now for who copied who.  My point is - we might have reached a similar point with gaming. But it doesn't mean people can't be original anymore. There's just a lot of money to be made in this industry so inevitably shit gets copy pasted more often than it should because successful games act like formula bases for others to "improve" upon. However, it ain't always in the best interest to make an improvement or be original - attempts to make weird shit can backfire. Look at all the souls like games that have popped up over the years - they're all essentially the same formula just used in different contexts. And for better or worse it works and people are into that shit. I think in the end devs are afraid to experiment and it's understandable as any given company is just trying to run a business.  Still, there's always some creative genius that produces something truly original once in a while. It's just very rare.
This just makes you wonder; what was the ORIGINAL original game?   The answer: Bookworm Adventures

IS THAT A DARK SOULS REFERENCE?
The problem is unoriginal reviews, not unoriginal games. What does "It's like Dark Souls" even mean?  Difficulty? Trial and error? Weapon upgrade crafting? Lack of music outside of boss encounters? Gigantic bosses? A "souls-esque" soundtrack? A dodge roll? A shield? Any functionality that serves to lessen damage you might take from an attack? A sad story? 3rd person camera controls? Slow attack animations? Fast attack animations? Stamina bars? Health bars?  Magic attacks? Combat commands mapped to the controller bumpers? Combat-oriented gameplay with hints of platforming mixed throughout?  Medieval armor? STYLIZED medieval armor! Or does it just mean the reviewer rushed through the game so they can't explain it very well, and just decided to say the quickest surface-level comparison they can so they can make their money and move on to the next game?

Maybe I misread the argument dunkey's making, but I don't think there is a single game you can find out there that doesn't borrow from another game.  I hate to break it but every piece of art takes from things that already exist.  The level at which they do it of course can be judged, but simply judging the fact that games reuse mechanics from other games is a frankly dull and obvious thing to make mention of.  That's how art works and will always work.  If an artist came up with something completely uninspired by anything, well...it would be just that.  Uninspired.  Lame.  Hard to grasp and meaningless.  Games are no different.

I think in a lot of cases, this is less of an issue of games lacking originality and more of a failure of some game critics to describe a new game without alluding to other video games. Video games are an evolving medium, with each one to some degree borrowing from and building off of previous games, and it‚Äôs natural for us to compare what is new with that which we already know.

It's not that there's a lack of originality in video games. It's that there's a lack of originality in the DESCRIPTIONS of video games.
I don't really think this is a problem. From a reviewer's perspective, it's a really effective way to set a starting point for viewers' expectations. From a developer's perspective, taking inspiration from the past is just how art works, and it's how art has worked for centuries.  The problem isn't that people are stealing ideas from other games, the problem is that certain developers aren't adding enough of their own ideas on top of that inspiration.

I guess then the question is "How important is originality?" Especially when a game a clear improvement on a preexisting idea. I think it's fair to say that the original inspiration for a video game is rarely the best. With a few rare exceptions (breath of the wild) a game that comes out inspired by another game (so long as it's not a cheap clone) is usually going to be better, or add more to the concept, like Devil May Cry being the inspiration for games like Bayonetta and God of War, or Undertale being inspired by games like earthbound and chrono trigger. Even sequels are often inspired by the games before them. Originality is a good thing, so long as the game is good with it (Shadow of the Colossus) but making a game like Odama, a tactical war pinball simulator that uses a microphone to control troops, on the gamecube... eh not so much.   The real beef, again, is with games journalism not knowing how to describe a game without comparing it to Dark Souls. It really makes you FEEL like dark souls.

It's less about a lack of originality in at least most cases and more like how everybody used to call FPS games Doom clones. One game comes out with a new mechanic or formula, and then other developers try their own spin on that mechanic or formula. In some cases that's things like how most third person shooters borrowed the over the shoulder camera from Resident Evil 4 until it became an industry standard, or in some cases like Dark Souls and Rogue before it, the formula itself works so well that it becomes its own sub genre of games that many developers continue to make long after their release.
Art is a fad
I'd expect crowbcat to make this video
Damn bro, Zelda goes places
Sakuro shedows die twice
Part of this issue may stem from the fact that it's kinda hard to talk about gameplay succinctly. It's hard to sum up Dark Souls combat in just a sentence. It's not just about the mechanics, but their effect on the player. Dark Souls and Breath of the Wild are both third person ARPGs with an emphasis on exploration, but are hugely different experiences. It also may have to do with the fact that these games kind of invented a genre, but there's not a name for them yet (even though dark souls has literally been a titanic influence for the past decade. Souls-like is the best we get?). They're hard to pin down to a descriptive phrase. Notice how all the games Dunkey mentioned are combat/mechanics oriented. No one called What Remains of Edith Finch a Gone-Home-Like because we have a name for that genre: walking simulator.
Thank you Dark Souls

I think people often confuse originality and quality, is every original product or idea good? No for ex. Death stranding it was way too polarising for commercial art, is every replicated idea bad? No for ex. Doom eternal it takes a lot of inspiration from a lot of fps games but it also tries to improve those ideas and therein lies the moral of the story that just cause something is replicating an already existing idea doesn't mean it can't be good in it's own right and just cause something is fresh out of someone's mind doesn't mean it will always be good.

I don‚Äôt get what the point of this video is. What is Dunkey‚Äôs even trying to say? Is it bad that some things inspire other things? Or that something can‚Äôt be good if it‚Äôs not 100% original? Neither of these is true at all. In fact, the best things today are based on, and improved from, other things. We can‚Äôt get Super Mario Odyssey without Super Mario 64, the GOOD Xenoblade games without previous Square RPGs, and even BotW without all of the previous Open-World games.  Notice the fact that all of my examples both took from previous products, but mixed it up with different ideas as well. EDIT: I realized only after writing all of this that the video is probably more making fun of cliched game criticism than actually lamenting a lack of originality in games themselves. My bad.  I mean, to the extent that any dunkey video should be taken at face value, I don't think it's necessarily a bad thing for games to draw inspiration from each other. For one, it's an inevitable part of the creative process. There's nothing new under the sun, in any medium, but it's through grabbing bits and pieces from other pieces of inspiration that 1) developers ultimately figure out their own creative voice, via some trial and error, and 2) elements that hadn't gone together before suddenly meld into something new.  Every game is a Dark Souls ripoff now, but Dark Souls was a ripoff of the early Zeldas and Metroids. The entire FPS genre used to be called "Doom clones." Someone coming up with a genuinely new idea is an extremely rare event in any medium, and even then they'll still probably rattle off all of their own influences that fed into it.  It's not entirely fair to say that the games Dunkey references in this video were created purely out of creative people following their influences, they're absolutely also jumping on the trends of past games which sold well in hopes that their game sells well. But still, I don't think it's completely fair to criticize designers for taking inspiration from great games that they love and trying to put their own spins on those works. That's just how creativity works in any medium.  Again, though, this is Dunkey, so who knows how seriously he takes any of this.

I think the problem is more on how game journalists describe other games as opposed to the originality of video games. The "this game is just like x game" line is just a generic, rehashed statement that all game journalists use to save them from actually describing a game's strengths and weaknesses. They are often inaccurate too, like how any game that poses some sort of challenge is automatically 'like dark souls', or how any adventure game with puzzle solving is zelda-like. Some are true, but I find most of them aren't.
Should have neen titled "unoriginality in videogame journalism"

Not just video games, my black friend. Pretty much every entertainment medium is in a barren, lifeless desert of creativity.
I don't think all of this is bad. There is no better way to tell an audience what to expect from a game than by comparing it to things that they may have been exposed to before. Obviously not everything in this video is that, but I've been able to make purchase decisions off of reviews like this where they mention similarities to another game that I don't like. It's a valuable way of introducing a new game to an audience that doesn't know what to expect from it, and the fact that the gaming medium at large is so focused on profit means that it is inherently useful to the industry.

Everything is often inspired by or derived by something else. The problem is when it's literally copying it. You can still have original ideas or a new spin or take on something already done. Sadly these gaming journalist reports don't see past "hurr dark souls durr" or "omg it's BotW!". Inspiration, not imitation, is what to aim for imo. Do not misunderstand that these words are usually not of the creators, but of 'curators' or whatever they call themselves. They are trained to give this bland, easy to understand description that will help the game appeal to wider audiences. This does not necessarily have to do with the originality of the game.
Saying game feels, looks or plays like another well known game is a very easy and effective way to give the viewer an idea of what to expect. There is nothing wrong with this.

...I mean... yeah that is a thing we tend to do But I think that's more of our monkey brains comparing one thing to another because of similarities and that. A rock is similar to a bolder, so we think of it as a 'big rock'.  So, in this case, if we see a platformer with a lot of jumping based mechanics with power ups. We think Mario usually even if it has a few twists.  I think sometimes we forget that these concepts were original at one point but there was a formula made that has been twisted and refined to the point where it's really hard not to think of games such as 'Dark Souls' for more grim games where things seem hopeless or Hades for games with large dungeons and hazards intertwined with the gameplay.  Really, we should be embracing the ideas that we are taking themes and gameplay elements among other things from other games and putting our own unique twist on it.  Someone make a Sekiro game with Kingdom Hearts combat or a game with Persona RPG aspects and combine them with fast-paced shooting of any other shooter.  Ya know, go the extra mile and all that.

I feel like a lot of these examples are more just reviewers finding a quick and easy way to convey the idea of what the game reminds them of. When they say, ‚Äúaction games like DMC or Bayonetta‚Äù I don‚Äôt think they mean it plays exactly like those games but it just belongs to the genre of fast paced action games. It‚Äôs a fun buzz phrase to say but just because they say it, doesn‚Äôt mean it‚Äôs 100% exactly what they mean. I don‚Äôt think IGN literally meant ‚ÄúSkyrim but with guns‚Äù when reviewing Far Cry 3. I imagine they follow up what they mean by that phrase by (hopefully) going into more detail. Basically, these phrases don‚Äôt fully represent games and therefore isn‚Äôt a solid sign of a lack of originality of games today. They‚Äôre perfectly fine phrases but they don‚Äôt encompass everything.  I‚Äôm more defending the games that just have similarities unlike the straight stealing of aesthetics and mechanics from Genshin Impact for example

Portal, Ninja Gaiden, Zelda, etc. So when the third one came out, it was a natural thing to make the combat more like Dark Souls. It's kind of the whole design philosophy behind the games. I wrote an essay once in college freshman Creative Writing. I titled it ‚ÄúThe Limit to Originilaity.‚Äù   It was just this. The idea that there comes a point where every story has been told, every idea played, every character written and all the tropes made. We are there now. Everything new can be related to something old, it‚Äôs not a bad thing necessarily, but it is important to know. How to make something completely new is the hard part.  I would later on come to learn that while this is the case, there is always room for improvements and changes to those ideas already played. It‚Äôs why we always have new technology and new stories are still being written and probably always will be.

This is something that happens everywhere, with everything. You‚Äôre immediately going to notice adjacent concepts. I feel like at this point, so many concepts and fundamentals have been tweaked and subverted so much that it truly is impossible to be completely original. I think what really constitutes as "originality in gaming" is when developers find a formula that has its influences, but is unique enough to become its own thing, then constantly refining and experimenting that core to make something that, while not original, is special.
